143218: Moonglove Changeling.author: Talcos
143218: Moonglove Changeling.text_parsed:
@tjwill22

While walls used to have a special property associated with their creature type (ie: defender), this is no longer true. And even under the old rules, I don't recall walls ever being able to block as many creatures as the controller chose (the only rule relating to walls was that walls could not attack).

As for this creature, meh. It's not bad in limited, as it fits in nicely as an elf, goblin, or treefolk, for instance.

146593: Scapeshift.author: kitsunewarlock
146593: Scapeshift.text_parsed:
This card is amazing with landfall.

And being able to search for land that itself counts the amount and type of land is amazing. Imagine sacrificing 4 land to get Urborg, Tomb of Yawgmoth, 1x Maze of Ith, and 2x Cabal Coffers...that's 6 mana next turn with +2 mana every time you play another land.

Alternatively if you control at least 6 land, you can search for Valakut, the Molten Pinnacle and a mixture of Mountains and "Fetchland". Searching for Fetchland lets you double your landfall.

146593: Scapeshift.author: Kitty_the_Kat
146593: Scapeshift.text_parsed:
God, this thing is an awesome card. Drop your silly basic lands and pull out lands that tap for 2, as well as combo lands (Tomb and Coffers for example?). It will also trigger your landfall, so having something like Rampaging Baloths or Ob Nixilis, the Fallen could do some serious damage.

On top of that, the land sac isn't part of the cost, so this getting countered wouldn't backfire like Devastating Summons would. Which is great! I wish more modern cards would do this.

152526: Door of Destinies.author: Jokergius
152526: Door of Destinies.text_parsed:
Let's see...Pros and Cons of Door of Destinies compared to Coat of Arms

DoD Pros:
~ The Counters are permanent.
~ SUPER Effective in token decks (Elves and Goblins)
~ You can bar your opponents creatures by saying only YOUR creature types.
~ It's an Artifact.

DoD Cons:
~ It's an artifact, ergo susceptible to Putrefy, Shatter, Naturalize, Disenchant, and so on.
~ You may have to play an Energy Chamber for this to be in its full potential quickly.

CoA Pros:
~ It's an Artifact
~ Gives your creatures MORE counters on your creatures.

CoA Cons:
~ Same as the first con for DoD
~ It costs one mana MORE to play, than DoD
~ It helps your opponents creatures as well.
~ You need at least two of the same type creature for it to GET the bonuses.

. . .
I still like DoD better...I wish they reprinted this instead of Coat of Arms in M10...or, hell, EVEN BOTH!!

152526: Door of Destinies.author: ScissorsLizard
152526: Door of Destinies.text_parsed:
Jokergius, you forgot one BIG con for Door of Destinies: it's slower. DoD has has to come out first, before you play all your spells. It needs to sit on the field (where it won't be until turn 4) while it accumulates counters. By contrast, Coat of Arms hits the field on turn 5 and instantly all those elves you've been dropping become 5/5's, and you can swing in for the win.

You can, of course, use Coretapper or Energy Chamber, but then you're devoting deckspace to cards that will most likely only combo with one card in your deck: the Door of Destinies. You'd probably find yourself drawing a few dead cards with that strategy.

152526: Door of Destinies.author: VoidedNote
152526: Door of Destinies.text_parsed:
@Jokergius
You forget that Coat of Arms works very well with with tokens because its for creature types and DoD does not gain counters if you play Dragon Fodder for example. You also must realize that Coat of Arms does help because if creatures share TWO creature types (elf warriors for example) they get +2/+2 for each occurrence of the double creature match (good with elves and goblins often)

With these two additional factors, then CoA is much better if you construct the right deck for it. Besides, it makes 4 player games much more interesting than just DoD on your own creature types.

152526: Door of Destinies.author: CeremonialBathory
152526: Door of Destinies.text_parsed: @dark_godzilla2002 - No. If I'm not mistaken (which is possible since I'm not a judge), his static ability only applies to Forests already on the battlefield, once they're on the battlefield. Since this looks at things coming to play and they are not yet creatures due to his ability, they don't yield a charge counter. I'm basing this on rulings to cards like Enchanted Evening, since it's ability is similar and doesn't cause everything in a deck to trigger Enchantress abilties. Hope that helps. :)

152526: Door of Destinies.author: jsttu
152526: Door of Destinies.text_parsed: What i think a lot of people here aren't noticing is that you have to cast the creature in order for it to count. That automatically rules out tokens, although they will get the buff if you add counters to it some other way. Other ways of getting creatures from your hand or deck that aren't cast do not count as well. It is still a great card, but it is harder to abuse than you guys think.

152526: Door of Destinies.author: Stinga
152526: Door of Destinies.text_parsed: Why are you all hating on Coat of Arms? It gives bonuses on the number of creatures not the spells. This means that a spell that gives you 5 1/1 tokens gives you 5 5/5 tokens with CoA whereas this gives you 5 1/1 tokens (or 2/2s if it is a tribal). This is great when you are playing a lot of creature spells, less so when you have a lot of creatures. You also gotta remember that this only gives the benefit whenever you play the spell so if you get it in your opener and you play an average amount of creatures each turn (1 on 1-2 2 on 3) you get 4 normal creatures on turn four, DoD is not retroactive. CoA would get you 4 4/4s or 5/5s. They both have their ups and downs. That said I run both in my sliver deck. ;)
152526: Door of Destinies.text_posted: Why are you all hating on Coat of Arms? It gives bonuses on the number of creatures not the spells. 152533: Supreme Exemplar.text_parsed:
I play an all color elemental evoke deck, and I've completely fallen in love with this card. A typical game usually has some combos along these lines...

Flamekin Harbinger (search) ---> Supreme Exemplar (Championing Harbinger, this should be played with an Incandescent Soulstoke's second ability, swing for 11) ---> Leaves play, you get to search out another with your newly reinstated Harbinger.

OR

Evoke a Shriekmaw, destroying a creature ---> Use Incandescent Soulstoke's ability to play this guy, swing for 11 ---> Leaves play, Shriekmaw kills something else. You get to kill two creatures, and you get 11 damage for 4 mana!!! XD

Hey gang, silly question that i think I already know the answer to but...

Do you discard your hand and draw cards simultaneously or do you do it sequentially? I would think you do both at once, but if not there are some opportunities to get silly when it comes to other spells and abilities regarding hand size.

Thanks in advance.

Oh also awesome card for red agro, usually having 5 cards in hand at the beginning of almost every turn no matter what you play can really allow you to bring on the heat, not to mention the synergy it can have with all sorts of graveyard stuff.

152539: Sensation Gorger.author: DukeofDellot
152539: Sensation Gorger.text_parsed:
@Jaguarkill

While abilities (and spells) are resolving, neither is priority passed nor are state based actions checked for.

For casual play, this means that once you look at that card, nobody can set spells or activate abilities (so you should ask for reactions before looking) until you decide whether or not to reveal. Once you reveal (if it's a goblin) people still can't do anything until they have dropped their hand then drawn four (after which YOU have priority as it's your turn, but for casual play don't worry about that too much).

Further, without state based actions being checked, any effect that cares about how many cards are in any player's hand ignore that moment when it is empty and go right to each player having four cards in hand. Hellbent (which checks for empty hands) doesn't happen, Maro doesn't die, but your opponents are allowed to drop their Loxodon Smiter as triggers still happen.

Hope this clears things up... And now that I've been reminded this exists, I wanna go make goblins for EDH... and if I'm lucky, I'll be "topping" some dudes, if you know what I mean.

152546: Maralen of the Mornsong.author: Mode
152546: Maralen of the Mornsong.text_parsed:
Your opponent unfortunately gets to make use of this effect at first. Although this will cost him/her 3 life, that player will find a response to get rid of Maralen or even fetch up something more awful, so you won't get to enjoy your tutoring effect without any preparation.

Yet fortunately, you get the opportunity to combine the better cards with her, that means you can both intervene during the tutor trigger with cards like Shadow of Doubt to inhibit them from fetching for one turn (although keep in mind the card's cantrip effect won't work) or Aven Mindcensor to minimize their selection effectively, or by simply countering the triggered ability with Stifle or Trickbind. If you got these or Shadow of Doubt on a stick you've created a nice softlock and simultaneously should be able to end the game since you topdeck every turn.
Additionally, the card-draw-disabling ability can also be made use of. This means no card advantage for anyone unless drawing is circumvented as on Fact or Fiction, Fathom Trawl, Merfolk Wayfinder or Mulch.

152546: Maralen of the Mornsong.author: BloodJunkie
152546: Maralen of the Mornsong.text_parsed:
This card makes the best mono black EDH general. Sure, she lets your opponents set up their lategame plans (which can be dangerous, especially in EDH). That's why no one kills her for the first few turns. And in those turns, you search for Necropotence and then Venser's Journal / Ivory Tower (I personally prefer the journal because it uncaps your handsize and provides better life gain than the tower, but sometimes you need to drop a life gain on turn 4, in which case the journal's hefty mana cost can become a problem, so put both in for optimal strategizing).
The thing that makes her perfect for an EDH general is that you don't have to wait to pull her from your 100 card deck. You play her 3rd turn from the command zone. Once she`s in play, you don`t need to pull anything else from your 100 card deck, the rest falls into place however you see fit.
Of course the Necropotence may turn you into a target, so my suggestion is lay it low for a while...

I think she would work best in the midst of an otherwise normal aggro-control deck so that you could just all of a sudden bring the game to a hault. Flash would make Maralen ridiculously good, as you would get first dibs at searching and could put the lock in place (aether vial seems viable, while things like leyline of anticipation, winding canyons and vedalken orrery are clunky and not extremely useful otherwise... scout's warning is somewhere on the fringe). Countermagic would be key also as u could counter anything your opponent finds on his or her first search and then try to lock the game out from there.

152546: Maralen of the Mornsong.author: Ragamander
152546: Maralen of the Mornsong.text_parsed:
Combos well with Anvil of Bogardan, since you always get to decide whether the searching or the discarding is done first. It locks everyone else out from playing anything but instants (so, if they have any instant speed artifact removal, any instant-speed 3+ damage burn, or any instant-speed kill-spell that hits black creatures, they're probably going to try to fetch one), but you still get whatever you want (you can be prepared). Teferi, Mage of Zhalfir closes that last gap, but good luck with the mana base.

Wait...Underground Sea, City of Brass, Underground River, Darkwater Catacombs, Watery Grave, Sunken Ruins, Drowned Catacomb, Creeping Tar Pit, Darkslick Shores...silly me.

152546: Maralen of the Mornsong.author: Sootoo
152546: Maralen of the Mornsong.text_parsed:
This is one of the nicest cards ever, but I think she doesn´t really make a good general herself, because without being able to play Vanishing on her, or to immediately play Stranglehold, she´s not really that useful.

I run her in a faerie tribal EDH deck, because that´s where she belongs to, IMO. And apart from becoming my personal tutor engine, if enchanted with Vanishing, I also use her to lock the game down with Mindlock Orb + Necropotence. With Necropotence in play you are the only one who is still able to "draw" cards, without having to lose 3 from Maralen every round. But most of the time, I also play the Ensnaring Bridge, before I use this combo, to stop others from being able to attack me, while I still can attack with my weeny faeries.

Apart from, using the AEther Vial, or Winding Canyons, it´s also good to just take an extra turn, after you played her, to be able to immediately tutor for Vanishing. I often use Notorious Throng for this, by casting it for its prowl cost.

152546: Maralen of the Mornsong.author: MattLynn
152546: Maralen of the Mornsong.text_parsed:
First search for Aven Mindcensor, then get the rest of your goodies.

Turns off ALL draw engines: Skullclamp, Well of Lost Dreams, Griselbrand, Consecrated Sphinx, etc.

Also turns dredge decks into blah...since they can't activate it (they don't ever DRAW a card).

Time Spiral becomes a free "all players shuffle their hands and graveyards into their library...that's it."

Jin-Gitaxias, Core Augur no longer mills you to death, but still reduces opponents' hand sizes...just in case they can still tutor for cards when Maralen is out.

Combos with: Necropotence, Scroll Rack, Thawing Glaciers for mana fixing, Stoneforge Mystic, Hermit Druid, Fauna Shaman, Dark Confidant, and all cycle or transmute cards. They all just "put" cards into your hand, not draw them.

Depending on when Maralen came into play: Teferi's Puzzle Box puts all hands into the bottom of owners' libraries...leaving you with Maralen's tutored card alone OR the box may just screw everybody out of cards entirely...every turn. I say that sounds like an auto-concede situation, either way...because Maralen can still attack each opponent.

152546: Maralen of the Mornsong.author: Ferlord
152546: Maralen of the Mornsong.text_parsed:
For EDH, try playing Discard.

Either use Greel, Mind Raker after they search, or something that can discard a card at any time (Scepter of Fugue doesn't work unfortunately).

Some cards that can also do this are Funeral Charm and Nezumi Shortfang.

It's tricky for this to work well, because discard has been made to work at sorcery speed (for good reasons).

152546: Maralen of the Mornsong.author: Traius
152546: Maralen of the Mornsong.text_parsed:
This card is really quite bad on its own. (yes, with stranglehold, it's amazing. But without ramps, that means you're choosing to play this on turn 5.....) It reads: "Opponent loses 3 life, searches for a removal, and it dies, then most likely outnumbers your creatures and hits you for ~3 damage and/or forcing you to chump block. (Hitting your opponent with a lightning bolt would have been a much better option)"

Alternatively, it reads, "Opponent searches for a counter-spell of some kind, counters your big thing. Because you can't block with this guy if you want to use its effects, you probably lose your grip on board control. If he countered with a mana drain, he's gained a lot of mana and almost certainly has board control."

Finally, it could read: "Opponent searches for a boss card you didn't know about/didn't think about, pwns, you, and you lose the game."

152546: Maralen of the Mornsong.author: SirLibraryEater
152546: Maralen of the Mornsong.text_parsed:
This card made me legitimately drool the first time I read it.
Ever since I have been playing Magic I've wanted an enchantment or an artifact that says something along the lines of "Whenever a player would draw a card, that player instead searches his or her library for a card, then puts that card into his or her hand."
This is the closest I can find, and it's legendary so I can have superhappyfuntimes in EDH with her, especially with all the infinite combos possible in monoblack.
*YAAAAY*

@Godlovesme
Then your opponent does not win, because they can't draw cards because of Maralen. If you can get rid of the Maniac before Maralen dies, you're in business.
Also take English lessons please.

@Traius
That's why this card shines in multiplayer and EDH. Your opponents instead want to keep you around because you let them tutor every turn and until you can make yourself a threat again, you aren't the target of your opponents and they fight it out until you can combo out some silliness and go infinite and win the game in ultimate glory.

152549: Vendilion Clique.author: sporvan
152549: Vendilion Clique.text_parsed: Iliona! Veesa! Endry! The Vendilion Clique is absolutely amazing. A fast, highly efficient card with an aggressive power to boot. What makes the siblings so fantastic is that they can pry the minds of your opponents and make them get rid of their most prized card - this literally swings games for you. Of course you should always remember you can use their ability on yourself to cycle away cards that you don't need, for example a Bitterblossom when you're low on life. The Flash ability is just extra power. When you need a job done, call the siblings!

152549: Vendilion Clique.author: UNHINGEDMAN
152549: Vendilion Clique.text_parsed:
I find this card strategically difficult. The usual choice is to bounce one of your oponnent's bombs but what if you choose to cycle one of their cards and they have total jank? you give them the advantage of gaining a new card but unless it is paired with other cards that view the opponent's hand there is no way of knowing if it is strategically better to bounce your card or their card.

This card is pretty ridiculous of course but it is by no means a tarmogoyf-esque cast then beat face card, it requires finesse and timing but can severely swing the game iny our favor.

So.. You just remember that.. PAL.

152553: Walker of the Grove.author: Oblivax
152553: Walker of the Grove.text_parsed: The first time i saw someone use a blink to get around the evoke sacrifice, I thought it seemed a little fishy, but i let it pass.  If you review the rules, specifically 702.72a, it's very clear that the sacrifice is PART of the casting cost, not a triggered effect.  Failure to sacrifice the creature makes the evoke fizzle and the creature goes to the graveyard.  It doesn't matter if the creature leaves the battlefield, it still must be sacrificed to fulfill the evoke cost. Any judge that misses this obviously hasn't read the rules closely enough.
152553: Walker of the Grove.text_posted: The first time i saw someone use a blink to get around the evoke sacrifice, I thought it seemed a little fishy, but i let it pass.  If you review the rules, specifically 702.72a, it's very clear that the sacrifice is PART of the casting cost, not a triggered effect.  Failure to sacrifice the creature makes the evoke fizzle and the creature goes to the graveyard.  It doesn't matter if the creature leaves the battlefield, it still must be sacrificed to fulfill the evoke cost. Any judge that misses this obviously hasn't read the rules closely enough.

152553: Walker of the Grove.author: Saraneth888
152553: Walker of the Grove.text_parsed:
@Oblivax - Actually, if you read rule 701.72 carefully, you'll see that the two triggers have nothing to do with each other. When an evoke creature is cast (regardless of if its evoke cost was paid) there are 2 triggers when it enters the battlefield. The first is the obvious enters/leaves the battlefield ability, and the second is the trigger "when this permanent enters the battlefield, if its evoke cost was paid, its controller sacrifices it". The two triggers are put onto the stack at the same time, in whatever order you choose - and the two triggers are independent of one another, meaning that the enters/leaves the battlefield trigger will trigger and resolve regardless of whether the creature has changed zones.

Now if you were to flicker the creature with those two triggers on the stack, the creature would re-enter as a new permanent (whose evoke cost was NOT payed), and the sacrifice trigger would simply fizzle.

This is to say that blinking an Evoke creature does in fact work.

152556: Heritage Druid.author: Donovan_Fabian
152556: Heritage Druid.text_parsed: What makes this card so ridiculously unfair that most people overlook, and is something not seen on many cards before lorwyn, is that it doesn't say "tap this card and 2 elves" and have a tap symbol.  Rather it gives you the option to tap 3 elves, meaning summoning sickness rules don't apply.  So, for example, if you have many elves that all cost only 1 mana or are reduced in mana cost by a banneret creature, you can basically empty your hand into play the minute you play her.  First turn, llanowar elf, second turn elvish visionary, third turn heritage druid, use extra 4 mana from two mana producing creatures and lands to cast more elves, tap all elves to cast further elves, which also tap, and cast the rest of the elves you have.  Once saw someone drop 10 elves on turn 4 with it.  These rules also hold true for merfolk decks, they don't actually have to tap such as when they are attacking, they can tap anytime; and enchantments that say merfolk on them count as merfolk, this is also true of elves so you can tap an elf type enchantment for heritage druid.  Why wotc made it this way I have no idea, since its pretty outrageous, but it does allow you to do some insanely crazy elf deck shinnenigans.  Just beware your opponent doesn't have firespout, volcanic fall out, lavalanche, or jund charm, because emptying your whole hand full of elves to have them burned away is not fun.
152556: Heritage Druid.text_posted: What makes this card so ridiculously unfair that most people overlook, and is something not seen on many cards before lorwyn, is that it doesn't say "tap this card and 2 elves" and have a tap symbol.  Rather it gives you the option to tap 3 elves, meaning summoning sickness rules don't apply.  So, for example, if you have many elves that all cost only 1 mana or are reduced in mana cost by a banneret creature, you can basically empty your hand into play the minute you play her.  First turn, llanowar elf, second turn elvish visionary, third turn heritage druid, use extra 4 mana from two mana producing creatures and lands to cast more elves, tap all elves to cast further elves, which also tap, and cast the rest of the elves you have.  Once saw someone drop 10 elves on turn 4 with it.  These rules also hold true for merfolk decks, they don't actually have to tap such as when they are attacking, they can tap anytime; and enchantments that say merfolk on them count as merfolk, this is also true of elves so you can tap an elf type enchantment for heritage druid.  Why wotc made it this way I have no idea, since its pretty outrageous, but it does allow you to do some insanely crazy elf deck shinnenigans.  Just beware your opponent doesn't have firespout, volcanic fall out, lavalanche, or jund charm, because emptying your whole hand full of elves to have them burned away is not fun.

152556: Heritage Druid.author: Temple_Garden
152556: Heritage Druid.text_parsed:
Combines well with Lys Alana Huntmaster and cantrip elves such as Elvish Visionary and Masked Admirers. Often you will be able to to continually tap the elf you cast and the token generated to cast the new elf you drew. Be cautious of board sweepers, it's easy to empty your hand with this card and be hit by a Day of Judgement the next turn.

This guy can also trigger Quest for Renewal very easily, which could help with the drawback from tapping all your creatures and leaving yourself open to attack - especially after you just cast a massive Joraga Warcaller - all those massive tapped elves don't look so good when lethal creature damage is coming through. Possibly useful with Chord of Calling.

152556: Heritage Druid.author: fissionessence
152556: Heritage Druid.text_parsed:
Andrew's Occasional Random Card of the Day #15 - 7/12/2011 - Heritage Druid

I'm not sure why all those elf spirits she's watching are so tiny.

Anyway, I imagine elf grouping up into threes and holding hands for their little mana rituals.

Okay, okay. I've never been a fan of 'Elf decks', and I don't tend to play formats where Elfball prevailed, so I've never seen this Druid in action. Being aware of cards like Glimpse of Nature, though, I can definitely imagine her being pretty silly. I would be interested to hear an experienced 'Elf deck' player's opinion on her versus Birchlore Rangers, though. Obviously the rangers make less mana, but is the color and/or number of Elves required to activate an issue?

Not having much to say on her power level, or even the design of such a straightforward card, I can comment a bit on the flavor connection. The flavor text hints that the tiny spirit people are the 'great spirits of age and those of the past' and that she 'prunes secrets from lineage', but it seems that her ability to allow other Elves to make mana indicates that she's teaching others rather than learning. I can suppose that the 'secrets' she's learning from the elders are on how to generate mana, perhaps from some such as Llanowar Elves (although not them in particular, considering the planar difference), but I don't really see anywhere in her title or flavor text or art that suggests she's allowing others the same skill.

152556: Heritage Druid.author: MattLynn
152556: Heritage Druid.text_parsed:
I think the ghosts are Elvish Spirit Guides.
Fyndhorn, Llanowar, Skyshroud, Quiron, Mul-Daya, Gilt-Leaf...all elves produce mana as part of the array of tribal abilities. Part of their heritage, or elvish legacy, is mana bonds. The ancestors show the heritage Druid (who acts as a medium of ancient knowledge) and shows those of her blood how to use innate abilities.

Consider this: Radha, Heir to Keld is an elf, but NOT a Druid, yet can still show how the bloodline allows mana bonds to be a tribal ability and not just an occupational one.

152571: Offalsnout.author: Oblivax
152571: Offalsnout.text_parsed: The first time i saw someone use a blink to get around the evoke sacrifice, I thought it seemed a little fishy, but i let it pass.  If you review the rules, specifically 702.72a, it's very clear that the sacrifice is PART of the casting cost, not a triggered effect.  Failure to sacrifice the creature makes the evoke fizzle and the creature goes to the graveyard.  It doesn't matter if the creature leaves the battlefield, it still must be sacrificed to fulfill the evoke cost. Any judge that misses this obviously hasn't read the rules closely enough.

This card is amazing and makes just too much fun. Easily my favorite sorcery card in this game.

I just wish, that the tokens weren´t just black, but black/blue, or at least blue. This way, the Faerie Swarm finally would be a little bit more useful, since it´s really hard for blue to get enough blue permanents out, compared to colors like green, for example. Even with Oona it´s really not that easy to make a good amount of tokens, since most people just scoop, as soon as you go infinite with her, and exile their libraries.

However, I definitely give this card a 5/5. Art is just awesome too, like in almost all faerie cards.

Faeries FTW!!!

Horrible card. Slow sorcery speed, costs a whooping four mana, and killing two creatures at once works only if you find two creatures, who's power is higher or equal to each others toughness. Very bad card.

The only good thing about this card is that it's the creatures which deal the damage, not the spell. So deathtouch works, and it can trigger the abilities of some vampires, which get counters or something when they kill a creature. Still, very narrow and bad card.

152587: Frogtosser Banneret.author: RunedServitor
152587: Frogtosser Banneret.text_parsed:
When you've actually played this in a Prowl deck, you find out how good it is. These are all the awesome cards you can play on turn one with a Swamp, Dark Ritual, and this: Oona's Blackguard, Noggin Whack, Morsel Theft, Stinkdrinker Bandit, Earwig Squad, Auntie's Snitch, Cloak and Dagger, Weirding Shaman, and Warren Weirding. Or you could play another of these!

Stinkdrinker Bandit is probably my fave, though. If they still fail to muster any blockers for the next turn, that's seven to the face, on the second turn. If you went first, it's entirely possible they won't have any blockers.

152587: Frogtosser Banneret.author: MRK1
152587: Frogtosser Banneret.text_parsed:
I used to run this guy in a monoblack rogue deck. However I came across a few issues that spurred me to remove him.

First: he occupies the same 2 CMC slot that makes up three fourths of my deck and I would find myself casting an evasive prowl enabler instead of him more often than not.

Second: because most of my deck is so cheap, his ability serves only to help me overextend. Anything that doesn't cost 2 prowls for 2 (except Earwig Squad) and that's cheap enough for me.

Third: beyond his cost reducing ability, he provided nothing else but a non-evasive 1/1 body for 2.
Haste gave only a small window for him to be a viable attacker and I'd lose the cost reduction if I used him as a blocker so what's the point?

Frogtosser, I love you bro but you're just not for me.
152587: Frogtosser Banneret.text_posted:
I used to run this guy in a monoblack rogue deck.  However I came across a few issues that spurred me to remove him.

First: he occupies the same 2 CMC slot that makes up three fourths of my deck and I would find myself casting an evasive prowl enabler instead of him more often than not.

Second: because most of my deck is so cheap, his ability serves only to help me overextend.  Anything that doesn't cost 2 prowls for 2 (except [autocard]Earwig Squad[/autocard]) and that's cheap enough for me.

Third: beyond his cost reducing ability, he provided nothing else but a non-evasive 1/1 body for 2.
Haste gave only a small window for him to be a viable attacker and I'd lose the cost reduction if I used him as a blocker so what's the point?

Frogtosser, I love you bro but you're just not for me.

152587: Frogtosser Banneret.author: Stinga
152587: Frogtosser Banneret.text_parsed:
You guys have inspired me to make a great legacy deck with this card. Just check out this play!

Turn one: Gemstone Cavern (put into play at the beginning of the game), Swamp lotus petal (hand size four). Black lotus for blue and triple ancestral recall (hand size nine) then play a mox jet. Crack the petal and use the Jet to summon this guy. (hand size seven). Now, use the gemstone cavern for red, casting Infernal Plunge on this guy (see! He is vital!). Use the red mana for Manamorphose into Flash to put out Protein Hulk. Let it die and find two Myr Galvanizers. (Hand size five, 1 R floating). Use the red for Rite of Flame, this for another Manamorphose. Use this to flash out another Protein Hulk. Let it die as well, pulling out a Palladium Myr and three Tinder Walls. Sac them all (Hand size 2, 6 red floating.) Use the red to play Fervor and produce infinite mana with the Myr. Manamorphose into Braingeyser and draw your entire deck. Cast Gemstone Array and use it to make whatever colour you need. Cast Djinn Illuminatus (Deck in hand, 99999999 colourless floating). Now Spawnsire of Ulamog and Battle of Wits. Then replicate Living wish with the Djinn Illuminatus for three hundred and ninety eight Bog Hoodlums (keeping to the goblin tribal of this deck). Then use the Spawnsire to pull two Emrakul the Eons Torn onto the battlefield. Float a billion mana of each colour then "kick" Rout in response to the spawnsire, killing all your hoodlums. The Emrakuls resolve and die to the legend rule, shuffling your 398 bog hoodlums and themselves into your library. Mindbreak trap and Quickened Stone Rain everything they try to do and win at the start of your next turn with Battle of wits! This card gets 5/5 for making that possible!

152588: Stonehewer Giant.author: Mode
152588: Stonehewer Giant.text_parsed:
a very powerful card in an equipment deck, which is normally not that powerful anyways.
you might even use this guy to bring out the Kaldra combo, which would normally be quite overcosted.
when you tutor Sunforger it effectively allows you casting any red or white instant spell with cmc 4 or less for , which isn't bad either - imagine the combo potential. Crush Underfoot might be useful if your Stonehewer Giant is already equipped, or simply searching for a Heartseeker and equipping another creature should be an easier way to get rid of it.
i'd advise searching Whispersilk Cloak at first to make it harder for your opponent to get rid of him. The great advantage is the fact that his ability still lets you attach tutored equipments to him - but you can't equip any others then, since these are targeted.
if you can get a Shield of Kaldra or find a way to regenerate the Giant, and hit your opponent with a Worldslayer equipped you should be able to end the game...although that takes a lot of time and won't work out most often, though.

152588: Stonehewer Giant.author: Kelptic183
152588: Stonehewer Giant.text_parsed:
An amazing card. You can use it during combat to equip him or another monster with an equipment before damage is declared. Say you swing with this guy: Your opponent can choose to chump block, in which case you tap him and grab a Loxodon Warhammer, block with something bigger, in which case you grab say Shield of Kaldra or Runechanted Pike, or they could let him through, in which case you can grab Worldslayer or Grafted Exoskeleton.

However, my favorite card to equip him with is Umbral Mantle. Assuming you have a lot of mana, you can equip multiple cards from your deck in combat. Equipping just the Mantle and Grafted Exoskeleton is 8 poison, possibly game if you can kick Mantle twice. If they block, equip with both the Shield of Kaldra and the Sword of Kaldra to exile the blocker. The possibilities are endless. 5/5

152595: Preeminent Captain.author: Vinifera7
152595: Preeminent Captain.text_parsed:
@pensaint:
When you attack with Preeminent Captain, he allows you to put a soldier onto the battlefield tapped and attacking. If you use this to get a second Captain, his ability will not trigger because when he entered the battlefield under your control he was already attacking; you haven't declared an attack with him.

However, using Preeminent Captain to blast in a high-costing soldier like Captain of the Watch is almost always a good play. You'd have two 3/3 attackers, and an additional three 2/2's waiting on the defense.

152595: Preeminent Captain.author: Mode
152595: Preeminent Captain.text_parsed:
Captain of the Watch is likely the best choice for monowhite.

But have your thought of splashing blue? (Although it's not even urgently necessary:)
Play him with Sun Quan, Lord of Wu, and your attackers will likely all survive since your opponent most probably won't have any creatures with Horsemanship.
In other words, while Su Quan is in play, all your creatures will be pretty much unblockable. And he's a 4/4 himself. Sounds pretty devasting for something caused by an attack from a three-drop.
Sun Ce, Young Conquerer also does a good job since he can unsummon your biggest threat (or maybe even Captain of the Watch if you want to use her cip/etb trigger again.)

152604: Cloak and Dagger.author: Toddington
152604: Cloak and Dagger.text_parsed: What happens when you have two of these out, and you try to equip a Rogue using the enter the battlefield ability? Both abilities go on the stack, and the first resolves. The creature now has Shroud. Does the second Cloak and Dagger still equip, because the Rogue was targeted before it had Shroud, or does the equip ability fizzle on accounts of the Shroud?
152604: Cloak and Dagger.text_posted: What happens when you have two of these out, and you try to equip a Rogue using the enter the battlefield ability? Both abilities go on the stack, and the first resolves. The creature now has Shroud. Does the second Cloak and Dagger still equip, because the Rogue was targeted before it had Shroud, or does the equip ability fizzle on accounts of the Shroud?

152604: Cloak and Dagger.author: AColonyOfAnts
152604: Cloak and Dagger.text_parsed:
@ justicarphaeton

You're doing it wrong if you're paying the equip cost.

@ Toddington

The Rogue ETB equip effect is not targeted; therefore it circumvents shroud. A Neurok Commando can still be equipped with Cloak and Dagger, but only upon entering the battlefield. Likewise can be said about any other rogue that is still in the process of triggering any ETB effects; they can have two equipped, but ONLY if you allow both triggers to resolve. If you equip one Cloak and Dagger and neglect to equip the other to the same creature, you cannot pay the equip cost to attach it (the second) to the same creature as long as the other Cloak and Dagger remains equipped.
152604: Cloak and Dagger.text_posted:
@ justicarphaeton

You're doing it wrong if you're paying the equip cost.

@ Toddington

The Rogue ETB equip effect is not targeted; therefore it circumvents shroud.  A [autocard]Neurok Commando[/autocard] can still be equipped with Cloak and Dagger, but only upon entering the battlefield.  Likewise can be said about any other rogue that is still in the process of triggering any ETB effects; they can have two equipped, but ONLY if you allow both triggers to resolve.  If you equip one Cloak and Dagger and neglect to equip the other to the same creature, you cannot pay the equip cost to attach it (the second) to the same creature as long as the other Cloak and Dagger remains equipped.

The guy is pretty average.
For 5 mana you get 10 toughness to block with or 6 power to attack with, which is actually nice (but you risk of losing lands). You can also use him as land destruction. Play that tomb of yawgmoth so your opponents lands are swamps, turn two into creatures, and then kill them as creature removal.

No great card, but fun for some casual decks.

With some untap effects, you might get a sizeable force. Late game, you don't really care about your lands so much, and you have repeateable, expendable troops. And at 5 toughness, they're going to be surprisingly hard to kill. Provides creatures for sacrifice outlets in a pinch. Forces me to use sentence fragments.

Generally, it's a neat trick. Not bad at all.

152616: Redeem the Lost.author: c0unter
152616: Redeem the Lost.text_parsed: If you cast this on a creature, and you win the clash, could you re-cast it instantly? I mean, for example, your opponent casts a lightning bolt on your creature, then you cast Redeem the Lost and you win the clash (i.e. RtL returns to your hand), then your opponent casts a second lightning bolt; could you cast this again in response of the second LB?
152616: Redeem the Lost.text_posted: If you cast this on a creature, and you win the clash, could you re-cast it instantly? I mean, for example, your opponent casts a lightning bolt on your creature, then you cast Redeem the Lost and you win the clash (i.e. RtL returns to your hand), then your opponent casts a second lightning bolt; could you cast this again in response of the second LB?

152616: Redeem the Lost.author: TPmanW
152616: Redeem the Lost.text_parsed:
@cOunter:
Yes you can cast this twice in rapid succession. As soon as it resolves it returns to your hand, ready to be cast anew.
152616: Redeem the Lost.text_posted:
@cOunter:
Yes you can cast this twice in rapid succession. As soon as it resolves it returns to your hand, ready to be cast anew.

152616: Redeem the Lost.author: zipec
152616: Redeem the Lost.text_parsed:
@cOunter: But your opponent would probably cast the second Lightning Bolt on top of this. Since the clash and possible return to hand happens as a part of Redeem the Lost resolution, you wouldn't be able to cast it second time. And what more, the target of Redeem the Lost will be illegal target (dead, already in grave) at the time it resolves and the whole spell will be countered (no clash, no returning to hand)

Second point, if he let the Redeem the Lost resolve before casting second LB, you dont have to cast it again, because the creature has protection (from red in this case I assume) till the end of turn.

152619: Release the Ants.author: Superllama12
152619: Release the Ants.text_parsed:
This card sees Legacy play

Essentially, the deck Show and Tells an Omniscience into play, then casts Enter the Infinite, drawing your library and putting Emrakul, the Aeons Torn on top of your library. Then, you Cunning Wish for this card out of the sideboard and cast it for free an unlimited number of times to deal infinite damage to your opponent, and unless the opponent is playing Show and Tell with Emrakul, you win (I assume that if you see your opponent is playing Show and Tell as well, you just use plan B: Show and Tell Emrakul into play before they do)

Sure, it's a fringe strategy, mostly used for classiness. It's a lot more efficient to just play Sneak-and-Show Emrakul because you don't waste valuable sideboard slots for an otherwise dead card and you don't waste deck space for Omniscience and Enter the Infinite. But think about how awesome it would be to tell your friends after a Legacy tournament that "I killed a man using Release the Ants in the second most powerful, degenerate format in existence"

Other than this niche strategy, though, it sucks :(

152625: Reins of the Vinesteed.author: Mode
152625: Reins of the Vinesteed.text_parsed:
Merely an expensive Rancor variation for tribal decks.
It stays right on the battlefield so that's an upside - but the only one.
Unlike Rancor, you won't get the trigger if the creature gets exiled or bounced.
Providing +0/+1 more doesn't help much if the creature doesn't get any trample either.
This would have been decent for , or if it provided +4/+4 instead.
But as it is, it's very expensive for what it does and still leaves you at the risk of getting two-for-one'd.

The best use I could think of for this would be to use this on tokens and then sacrifice them for an effect that looks at the sacrificed creature's power and toughness like Greater Good. But even then, it still won't make the cut.
152625: Reins of the Vinesteed.text_posted:

This would have been decent for [1G], or if it provided +4/+4 instead.
But as it is, it's very expensive for what it does and still leaves you at the risk of getting two-for-one'd.

The best use I could think of for this would be to use this on tokens and then sacrifice them for an effect that looks at the sacrificed creature's power and toughness like [autocard]Greater Good[/autocard]. But even then, it still won't make the cut.

152625: Reins of the Vinesteed.author: Burningsickle
152625: Reins of the Vinesteed.text_parsed:
Rancor will usually be better... BUT, in a tribal/token deck, this needs to only be cast once, and the effect will bounce around as your creatures come and go. Most decks lack exile or bounce effects, so there is little need to worry about such removal, and you can always find a way to sac the creature beforehand.
3/5

152641: Final-Sting Faerie.author: MechaKraken
152641: Final-Sting Faerie.text_parsed:
Nice little surprise after combat has taken place. They'll usually be expecting Soul Reap or some other kill spell like Doom Blade. The upshot is that this can also target any creature as long as it was dealt damage. That's something that Death Mark, Go for the Throat, and other black kill spells cannot do. The exception is Murder, but for more, you can get a 2/2 flying creature with a useful tribe if you use this.

Also, combo's nicely with cards like prodigal pyromancer and Niv-Mizzet, Dracogenius =)

152643: Rhys the Exiled.author: Temple_Garden
152643: Rhys the Exiled.text_parsed:
Rhys shows how they needed to balance the Wellwisher. Life gain equal to the number of elves can build up very fast. His toughness is a little low to survive many attacks to try to pump him with things like Imperious Perfect or Bramblewood Paragon.

Regarding the legend rule: As long as they aren't the same card you can have both in play. If you have an Odyssey Kamahl, Pit Fighter in play and cast a 10th edition Kamahl, Pit Fighter , the legend rule will send both to the graveyard. If you had any Kamahl, Pit Fighter in play and cast Kamahl, Fist of Krosa, the legend rule sees them as different legends and both stay in play.
152643: Rhys the Exiled.text_posted:

If you had any [autocard]Kamahl, Pit Fighter[/autocard] in play and cast [autocard]Kamahl, Fist of Krosa[/autocard], the legend rule sees them as different legends and both stay in play.[/i]

152643: Rhys the Exiled.author: ddde
152643: Rhys the Exiled.text_parsed: Yep, the legend rule only cares if they have the entire name exactly the same.  The planeswalker rule, however, cares if their planeswalker type is the same.  If both Rhys cards were planeswalkers instead they would probably both have the type Rhys and could not be in play at the same time.
152643: Rhys the Exiled.text_posted: Yep, the legend rule only cares if they have the entire name exactly the same.  The planeswalker rule, however, cares if their planeswalker type is the same. 152648: Bitterblossom.author: sporvan
152648: Bitterblossom.text_parsed: The card that helped push Faeries into the spotlight with a victory condition that is very hard to remove. It provides Faerie decks with a stream of faeries to overwhelm your opponent or act as defenders at the cost of 1 life a turn. When the life-loss becomes too much target it with the Champion ability of your Mistbind Clique since it is a Tribal card. It also has excellent synergy with Scion of Oona (pumps ups the tokens and grants the enchantment Shroud) and Spellstutter Sprite. Playable across multiple formats and even in non-Faerie decks, this card is fantastic and well designed. A gift from Oona!

152648: Bitterblossom.author: WER386
152648: Bitterblossom.text_parsed:
Actually losing life IS important; you don't care about 1 life per turn loss until your on turn 11 and you foe has managed to get you into 2 life... In my opinion this is not too far (no, I'm not saying "kind of") from the Alara's Goblin Assault, of course, if you are going to play this, you must know how to get rid and/or protect this thing. It's not the typical card you put in every black deck just 'coz its good; but don't misunderstand me: this thing is a finisher dropped on turn 2, hard to remove, creature provider enchantment with loose drawback.
I'm just sick of seen 2-and-half colors decks just to wear the Bitterblossom because they got low quantity of creatures.
Just a reminder for most people who seem to have forgotten about this detail: this card was supposed to be used in the upgrade "going rogue" Morningtide theme deck and well, from there we got 2 decks: mono black rogues and the always loved and hated blue faeries.

152648: Bitterblossom.text_parsed:
Bitterblossom basically makes the fae archetype work, so it's basically an auto 5/5 for making such a powerhouse possible. I have never piloted Fae, but anyone who has even seen the deck run knows it deserves it.

Also, for those saying Tarmogoyf is a bad creature, get your head out of your ass and try playing with the card. Do you really like getting your comments given bad ratings because you say something stupid? It's one of the most cost effective beaters the game has. Who care if it's a vanilla creature with no abilities? It's usually one of the biggest bodies on the board for just 2cmc and is easily splashable. The card makes some Legacy decks work, which is a lot to ask of any card for that matter.

152648: Bitterblossom.author: Ferlord
152648: Bitterblossom.text_parsed:
Bitterblossom is such a deadly card. For any of those cards that require a mandatory sacrifice (Old Demons, for example), this is a perfect solution to that.

I run a Mono-Black Contamination Control deck, but I used Ornithopter's and Kobold's as my sacrifice outlets. If I can somehow Dark Ritual into Contamination on turn 1, I've essentially started a clock against non-artifact and non-black decks.

If I fetched out for a playset of this, I can do so much more without relying on the 0-cost creatures (although I have 24 in the deck)...

It is $12+ each, however...

152648: Bitterblossom.author: Aquillion
152648: Bitterblossom.text_parsed:
This is one of those cards where it's hard to realize just how powerful it is until you've seen it in action.

Consider. If your opponent lacks a way to block flying creatures, it will deal the following damage in the turns after it hits play. 0 + 1 + 2 + 3 + 4 + 5 + 6 = 21 damage after 7 turns, all on its own. That's roughly as much of a threat as a 3-power creature -- for two mana, with evasion. More importantly, it imposes that threat while being resistant to creature removal, slowing down only slightly if a single fairy is killed; and even enchantment removal is less valuable against it, because if they don't take it out early they still have to deal with the faeries it produced. And that's before you get into ways of boosting their power.

Swarming flying tokens is vicious. And that's just the most straightforward use for this card; there's lots of things you can combo it with -- or, if you're forced to use the tokens defensively, it's probably still going to buy you significant time.

152659: Shinewend.author: Cogspin
152659: Shinewend.text_parsed: Around the casual table, there's always that one guy who plays with an enchantment-heavy deck. You want to be able to deal with him, but you don't want to have to tweak your deck every time you play him. Cards like this help you do that: it's not the most efficient 1/1 flier, and it's certainly not the most efficient disenchant, but it can do either reasonably well depending on your situation. I actually prefer to run this over Disenchant in a casual deck for that reason.

152659: Shinewend.author: MechaKraken
152659: Shinewend.text_parsed:
This card is really bad. There are other 2 drop creatures that can sac themselves for free to destroy artifacts/enchantments. Such as Keening Apparition, Kami of Ancient Law, and Ronom Unicorn.

The one good thing about this card is that it has a useful tribe. But even then, there are better cards to run if you are playing elementals, even for the sideboard. If you can somehow manage to increase the +1/+1 counters on it for free, it may become more useful. Perhaps with Forced Adaptation or Mikaeus, the Lunarch. But again, that's more cards you need to make this useful, which is still pretty bad =/

Perhaps it can have a home in a highly specialized, direct-counter deck for enchantments, maybe Zur the Enchanter decks...

152664: Knowledge Exploitation.author: DarthParallax
152664: Knowledge Exploitation.text_parsed:
The first thing I'd like to point out is that you are eliminating a specific card from your opponent's deck. It's a bit like Jester's Cap or Nevermore in that way- lots of decks, this can plain cripple if you take their big bomb win condition. That would be worth 3U without the prowl keyword, so in Rogue Tribal it's already just fine.

On TOP of that, you get to play the card yourself. That would be very nice indeed at 3U mana, though 5UU seems a bit much. It's worth it to splash a couple Rogues, just for that.

Oh. I don't have to even pay the mana cost? Yeah, I would definitely pay 7 mana for that. And I would do whatever I could to make sure I get to cast this, either by filling up on Rogues, or by finding some decent Mana Ramp.

This is an auto-include in Commander, and by extension that means all Blue Commander decks probably want to have at least one Rogue creature. Not a whole lot of them, because not All Blue Commander decks NEED to be Rogue Tribal (not by a long shot), but you have room for one, and since Rogues are so often able to get Unblockable, you were probably already considering at least one in the first place. And maybe a '3 Rogue minimum' is not unreasonable, considering how powerful this card is.

152664: Knowledge Exploitation.author: Sliver_Legion
152664: Knowledge Exploitation.text_parsed:
"The first thing I'd like to point out is that you are eliminating a specific card from your opponent's deck. It's a bit like Jester's Cap or Nevermore in that way- lots of decks, this can plain cripple if you take their big bomb win condition. That would be worth 3U without the prowl keyword, so in Rogue Tribal it's already just fine."

Extract. You're welcome.

But seriously though, searching through an opponent's library and exiling one copy an instant or sorcery would be TERRIBLE at 3U. What if their only instants/sorceries are things like Rampant Growth that aren't relevant turn 4-ish anyway? Splashing black for Memoricide in your otherwise blue deck is much better if you really want to cast something for 4 that doesn't affect board position and barely affects your opponent's future draws anyway.

But on to the card itself.

Your later conclusion that every commander deck should run this...no, just no. Sure there's going to be times when it works out great, but it's not worth 7 mana (no, Commander is not "ignore all mana costs, the format") to search through an opponent's deck and find that the only big instants/sorceries in their deck are boardwipes...and your board position happens to be really good at the moment. And throwing a few bad rogues into your deck just to support this one card won't help anything, if you play a weak card with no real board impact like, I dunno, Inkfathom Infiltrator, you've given up a card for the sake of having a 20+ turn unblockable clock in a format where you don't want other players to be annoyed at you, oh and one card in your 99-card deck costs 3 mana less. Congratulations.

152667: Pulling Teeth.author: iondragonx
152667: Pulling Teeth.text_parsed:
Undervalued card.
The clash mechanic is the same as Scry 1 for both players plus a reveal. On top of that, you could get two cards for one and two mana. I don't see much downside. Black has little to control their library and the scry effect can filter things out that aren't needed. If the opponent keeps what he revealed, you can hit him with a Brain Pry, Cranial Extraction or Thought Hemorrhage. If he doesn't keep it, then you just Fatesealed 1.

152667: Pulling Teeth.author: Bobmacambob
152667: Pulling Teeth.text_parsed:
At worst, this is a 2 to cast one for one. Not that great, admittedly. But the additional scry 1 does give a liiittle bit of compensation (even if both players do it).
At best, this is a slightly less crazy Hymn to Tourach!!! Or a Gerrard's Verdict without the lifegain. + Scry 1, giving it some liiittle but of extra.
C'mon, we all love our 2 to cast discard 2 cards cards. An let's say you win the clash 40% of the time (I reckon it should be a bit more closer to 50%). On average, you're making your opponents discard 1.4 cards and having a scry 1. It's not too bad.
Then you could use the things that iondragonx says. But that's kinda true for all clash cards.

2 cards on the second turn is a biiig chunk of your hand. From experience, winning the clash in casual equates to winning the game. Losing the clash is still ok because the scry 1 DOES give you a bit of room to recover. In decks which you don't really do anything on turns 1 and 2 anyway, this is a fairly innovative addition for budget decks (especially because if you're not doing anything early, you're deck is likely to have more higher converted mana cost cards.... buuut maybe also more lands.. =\ )

I would say that this should be a 3.7 -3.8 card. After using it, it's not bad. Not bad at all.

Also, late game, when both players are in top-decking mode, unlike plain discard cards, Pulling Teeth lets you scry 1 while plain discard cards become slightly useless. At this point, there's no much difference between discarding 1 card and discarding 2 cards.

152682: Leaf-Crowned Elder.author: Tynansdtm
152682: Leaf-Crowned Elder.text_parsed: The word "play" is not obsolete in Magic. "Play" means "cast it if it's a spell, otherwise put it onto the battlefield if it's a land." You cast spells, but you play cards. Magus of the Future demonstrates why the distinction is necessary, and Oracle of Mul Daya would be meaningless without it.
152682: Leaf-Crowned Elder.text_posted: The word "play" is not obsolete in Magic. "Play" means "cast it if it's a spell, otherwise put it onto the battlefield if it's a land." You cast spells, but you play cards. [autocard]Magus of the Future[/autocard] demonstrates why the distinction is necessary, and [autocard]Oracle of Mul Daya[/autocard] would be meaningless without it.

152716: Reveillark.author: kashonismw
152716: Reveillark.text_parsed:
@Superllama12 - To my understanding the combo works like this...

Have a Reveillark in your graveyard, discarded for some various reason, along with the creature you want to reborn infinite times. Let say Murderous Redcap. Have a sac engine out, something like Fanatical Devotion, Martyr's Cause, Viscera Seer... whatever. Next play Body Double copying the Reveillark in the graveyard. Now here's the fun part, sac Body Double to activate the ability, return itself and the Redcap to the field. Sac the Redcap twice to deal 3 damage and put it in the graveyard again. Repeat.

This also works if you start off with a Body Double in the graveyard and Reveillark out instead

If you can't use the Body Double's Reveillark effect to bring its self back (I'm pretty sure you can, but anyway) you just need another Body Double in the graveyard so you can alternate between the two.

Hope this helps :)

152716: Reveillark.author: AlphaWolfs
152716: Reveillark.text_parsed:
Hm... I must say an interesting card to say the least. Thinking of making a 5 color elemental deck coming out with Avacyn Returns, and this is one of the few cards that sparked my interest. Imagen this, all my cards are uncountable? Since all Evoke cards are elemental to begin with, using Cavern of Souls (new card) will make all Elemental Spells uncountable.

That means, I now have my choice of Evoking cards for a fraction of their cost for an already appropriate cost (2/Black = Destroy non-black/artifact, 2/Blue = draw 2 cards, ect...). Adding THIS in there, means that when I cast it for its evoke cost, I can use OTHER cards that I ALREADY evoked from the graveyard AGAIN. And lets not forget the very much impotent Incandescent Soulstoke.

Lets put it this way, it turns all my Evoke Cards into evoke cost at instant speed, without the drawback of them becoming destroyed at the end of turn (or in this case, the benefit.) But seriously, that decreased the cost of down to ONLY to summon 2 other, 2/X creatures from the graveyard afterward. Meaning more evoking fun with elemental!

152716: Reveillark.author: Oblivax
152716: Reveillark.text_parsed: The first time i saw someone use a blink to get around the evoke sacrifice, I thought it seemed a little fishy, but i let it pass.  If you review the rules, specifically 702.72a, it's very clear that the sacrifice is PART of the casting cost, not a triggered effect.  Failure to sacrifice the creature makes the evoke fizzle and the creature goes to the graveyard.  It doesn't matter if the creature leaves the battlefield, it still must be sacrificed to fulfill the evoke cost. Any judge that misses this obviously hasn't read the rules closely enough.

152716: Reveillark.author: igniteice
152716: Reveillark.text_parsed:
A truly formidable card, one that requires other cards to support its ability, but with them, is devastatingly effective. With bounce and sac outlets, it is a card-drawing machine with Mulldrifter. It can be almost too abusive of mechanics to fairly play against; once the combo engine is in place, it's hard not to quit out of frustration.

@Oblivax
You don't understand the stack. The evoke cost isn't to sacrifice the creature. The evoke cost is exactly what is written on the card next to evoke. In this case it is 5W. You pay the evoke cost to put the creature into play. Sacrificing the same creature you are playing to pay the cost of playing that creature would never work, because the creature can't enter the battlefield (in this manner) unless you pay the cost. The cost would be sacrificing the creature. But it's still on the stack. Does that make sense?

So, no, sacrificing the creature is definitely not part of the cost. It is a trigger event set up by you paying the evoke cost. Once the creature enters the battlefield, the evoke trigger goes on the stack. Once that trigger resolves, you must sacrifice the creature. Before that trigger resolves, you may respond to it by playing something that bounces the creature. Once it leaves the battlefield in this manner for any reason, its other ability triggers (that lets you return two creatures to the battlefield). Then the sacrifice tries to resolve, but it sees the creature isn't there (or if it returned to the board, it sees a different creature). You therefore can't sacrifice it, and the sacrifice trigger fizzles.

152728: Wolf-Skull Shaman.author: Mode
152728: Wolf-Skull Shaman.text_parsed:
If you're making a Shaman tribal deck, combine this one with Oracle of Mul Daya.
(In block-constructed or for budget reasons, you can use Gilt-Leaf Seer)

In general i'd advise using Sensei's Divining Top or Mirri's Guile in a Shaman deck since most of them have effects that are dependant on your top card.

@made4ipod: You can't quite compare these, Garruk's companion has a cost of , which makes a huge difference if you run more than one color.
However, you can compare Wolf-Skull Shaman to the classic (which, by the way, coined the term "bear" for a 2/2 body).
Not that there were a ton of drops before that were strictly better than the bears (ignoring creature types), like Wild Mongrel for instance.
But this one is a pretty tough comparison to the bears nonetheless since (again, ignoring creature types) it can create further bears visually for free.

152736: Ink Dissolver.author: sonorhC
152736: Ink Dissolver.text_parsed: Mill does not "counter things before they're drawn". If someone draws something and then you counter it, they've still used up that draw, to no effect. If you mill them, though, they'll just draw whatever was underneath what you milled, and use that instead. There are ways to make milling work, but by itself, it's usually useless or worse.
152736: Ink Dissolver.text_posted: Mill does [i]not[/i] "counter things before they're drawn".  If someone draws something and then you counter it, they've still used up that draw, to no effect.  If you mill them, though, they'll just draw whatever was underneath what you milled, and use that instead.  There are ways to make milling work, but by itself, it's usually useless or worse.

152736: Ink Dissolver.author: Stinga
152736: Ink Dissolver.text_parsed: @BlackAlbino No. No it does not. Mill does NOTHING until you kill someone with it, much like damage. In fact, it is often worse than dealing damage because many decks use their yard as a resource. You mill random cards. They still draw random cards. Lets say you mill three lands. Great, you just "countered" three free turns of dead draw. The sheer randomness of it means that you are just as likely to push the opposition into drawing soothing they needed far down in the library that would have never seen in an ordinary game.

152830: Floodchaser.author: DoctorKenneth
152830: Floodchaser.text_parsed:
To be fair, blue doesn't get big creatures at common very often. When it does, they generally aren't too efficient. However, this is a better Sea Serpent, so props for that, I guess.

I think the main focus of the card is that it's a 6/6 for 6, not that it makes islands. I mean, this was printed in the same set as merfolk tribal, and THEY were the ones with islandwalk and the ability to make islands. I guess they didn't want to step into that tribe's territory too much. Though I think cards like this were the reason the Elemental tribe wasn't played much outside of red (and with the exception of Mulldrifter and Revellark, but they weren't really played alongside any of their elemental kin).

Evasion might be a bit iffy on this thing. I mean, it would fit flavourfully, sure, but sometimes a very unseeming little thing can turn a shit card into a very efficient one. A 6/6 islandwalker is really good for common blue.

152836: Revive the Fallen.author: ErikLauer
152836: Revive the Fallen.text_parsed:
Erik's Random card 6/11/2011

Morningtide had a re-design before it got to development. "Great designer search" winner Alexis Janson got to fill some holes, and made this card.

Kelly Digges tweaked the card so it would be more multiplayer friendly.

Other than that, it sailed through development. But would it sail through today?

I don't think so. The card doesn't really tell a good story. You get a creature spell back, and if you are lucky you keep this spell. That doesn't really resonate with me. But maybe it is intellectually stimulating. Maybe this creates new strategic situations; maybe, but my experience with this card wasn't that either. It isn't really worth building a deck around. When I have this in my hand instead of "raise dead" I am slightly less picky about the quality of the target, since I might get this back, and then the limiting factor on what I am doing could become mana instead of spells. But really this is raise dead.

I think we would try other black spell effects here. You could destroy a land, or give a creature an evasive ability. There are lots of black spell effects we could use, some of which are already used enough in the set already. After trying some others, we might decide this is the best we could do, or we might change it to a new one.

Development is picker now about cards like this, and I think that is for the better.

It's like [autocard]Fireblast[/autocard], only it deals 75% of the damage for [R] more, which completely defeats the purpose of a card like [autocard]Fireblast[/autocard], so it doesn't really matter that you get to save a single land.

And, despite all of this, it's still rather good in Mono-Red burn decks.

152870: Grimoire Thief.author: UltimaCenturion
152870: Grimoire Thief.text_parsed:
Hmmm...
Crackleburr and Painter's Servant?
Turn 1, play a land, streamhopper
2, land, play Painter's Servant, say everything is Blue and Red (and maybe black in case your opponent is running doomblade or shriekmaw)
3, land, play crackleburr,
4, land, tap 2 land, crackleburr, streamhopper, and this, deal 3 damage to opponent and mill (and get free counters,) tap 2 land and untap them all (and swing if possible, getting more mill) and bounce something.

If you want to take it farther:
5, land, smokebraider, tap 2 land, crackleburr, streamhopper, and this, deal 3 damage to opponent.
6, land, and start crackling. You'd get 6 cards and 6 damage right there, not counting if you attack this turn. That's a minimum thus far of 12 damage and 12 cards milled, 3 enemy stuff bounced, and a chance at countering stuff.

Try even throwing in vivid lands and disentomb, and bring your grimoire thief back when you counter with it! Weeeeeeeee!

Or maybe I'm just an idiot and this is too hard to pull off (and obviously it wouldn't go that well unless you were really lucky. You might want some counter spells in this deck, as well as some unblockables, and maybe some stuff that bounces stuff (other than crackleburr.)

But this would be okay with banishing knack (bounce something, mill,) but (if, as above, you're running red blue,) you can try "elemental mastery" and then make 2 3/1 red elementals with haste (until EoT) and mill!


The possibilities are endless! (Or maybe I'm just an idiot, which is all too possible. :/)

152870: Grimoire Thief.author: OmniMarconi67
152870: Grimoire Thief.text_parsed: The beauty of this and Nemesis of Reason is that they force your opponent to deal with them.  Nemesis of Reason is a great closer, but this is a better opener and a slightly better card in my opinion because of the early play potential.  When you play this you force your opponent to waste a turn and resources dealing with it (whether countering, bolting, or holding back some of the attack squad to block and try to kill it), which can be crucial early on, and if your opponent can't then you've got him right where you want him.

152870: Grimoire Thief.author: BelloAbril
152870: Grimoire Thief.text_parsed:
Chrisrawr why would you want a ornithopter when you could have a card drawing device likePonder or a Puresight Merrow if you didnt get the right cards, heck, you cant even win on turn 3 with that combo, remember that paradise mantle casting cost is 0 and its equip cost is 1, so how are you supposed to drop freed from reality AND paradise mantle on the same turn? You would have to tap Grimoire Thief to get the last third mana and then it would be pointless and take a whole new turn to use it's hability. Meanwhile your opponent will do nothing? Grimoire Thief screams loud 'IM A COMBO ENGINE, PLEASE KILL ME OR YOU WILL LOSE' for a whole 3 turns while you are completely tapped out, how are you supposed to stop them to kill your creature? Only a moron would let that happen.

Now, for people that look for serious uses for this card, spell pierce, spiketal drakeling and cursecatcher are the way to go. They can assure that your opponent's won't drop their 'bombs' early in the game. Even if they attempt to, make sure you have some counter on your hand so they will waste 7 mana to drop that winning creature just to be owned by a mana leak. If you succesfully screw him twice, you have the psychological advantage, having a 'permission' deck allows you to win more turns even if you dont have counters because they will be afraid of playing their best spells.

Also remember to bring unsummon in case your opponent use a non counterable hability (triggered habilities, volcanic fallout like spells, planeswalker's skills, etc) or to save your ass in case your opponent has gone too far and you can control him to win more time by returning their strong creatures.

152870: Grimoire Thief.author: Guest513736147
152870: Grimoire Thief.text_parsed:
@MDStrawHat:

It doesn't counter those spells for the rest of the game, just for the one time you activate it. Good thing, too, or Swift Silence would be insanely powerful. The awkward wording with "all" is because it can counter multiple spells at once. Imagine this:

You're playing against Jund. You've just removed, among other things, a Bloodbraid Elf and a Sprouting Thrinax from the game using the Thief. They play a different copy of Bloodbraid Elf, cascading into a Sprouting Thrinax. You sacrifice your Thief, and counter both spells. However, the next time he plays anything you previously removed with the Thief, it resolves as normal.

152870: Grimoire Thief.author: Lateralis0ne
152870: Grimoire Thief.text_parsed:
WACKY COMBO DECK TIME!

Merfolk Combo {W}{U}

CREATURES - 34

4 Merrow Reejerey
4 Arctic Merfolk
4 Drowner of Secrets
4 Stonybrook Banneret
4 Fallowsage
4 Grimoire Thief
4 Merfolk Sovereign
3 Stonybrook Schoolmaster
3 Wanderwine Prophets

SPELLS - 8

4 High Tide
4 Merrow Commerce

LANDS - 18

10 Island
6 Plains
2 Hallowed Fountain

SYNOPSIS:

Basically, power out Stonybrook Banneret, Merrow Reejerey, Grimoire Thief, and Drowner of Secrets as early as possible, tap the Grimoire Thief using Drowner of Secrets' ability, then play as many high tides as you can in one turn to continuously bounce two Arctic Merfolk in and out of play. Every time you do, untap the Grimoire Thief using Merrow Reejerey's ability, and mill as many cards from your opponent's library as possible. Remember, if you have multiple Reejerey's, Thiefs and Drowners, you can use the above engine on each of those engines every time an Arctic Merfolk comes into play. You could very easily get an entire player's library into the exiled zone in one turn, if played correctly.

Also, use the Merfolk Sovereigns and Reejerey's to pump up your Merfolk creatures, and use Stonybrook Schoolmaster the Drowner/Reejerey/Banneret/Arctic engine to create many, many tokens. Attack to your heart's content at that point.

Finally, the Wanderwine Prophets can be powered out using High Tide, and then use the token engine described above to continuously sac creatures, taking multiple turns. This also allows for large attack phases uninterrupted by your opponent(s), or to keep the milling going from the mill engine above.

And of course, draw all the cards you need with Fallowsage and either tap engine that works for your situation.

Enjoy!

152878: Cenn's Tactician.author: dfarrey
152878: Cenn's Tactician.text_parsed: I have a question on this one.  When a creature blocks multiple creatures, which player determines the damage order?  Does it work like banding, like blocking with multiple creatures, or something entirely different?
152878: Cenn's Tactician.text_posted: I have a question on this one.  When a creature blocks multiple creatures, which player determines the damage order?  Does it work like banding, like blocking with multiple creatures, or something entirely different?

152878: Cenn's Tactician.author: SweLink88
152878: Cenn's Tactician.text_parsed:
"When a creature blocks multiple creatures, which player determines the damage order? Does it work like banding, like blocking with multiple creatures, or something entirely different?"

From what I've read, when you block more than one creature with a single creature, you choose how your creature's blocking damage is assigned.
For example: you have a 2/2 Glory Seeker and Cenn's Tactician on the battlefield, and your Seeker has two +1/+1 counters on it. During his/her declare attackers step, your opponent decides to attack with a 1/1 Eager Cadet and a 1/3 Lumengrid Warden.
You block Cadet and the Warden with your Seeker. As a result, you choose how your Seeker's damage is assigned.

You can either assign:
* 0 damage to the Cadet, 4 damage to the Warden.
* 1 damage to the Cadet, 3 damage to the Warden.
* 2 damage to the Cadet, 2 damage to the Warden.
* 3 damage to the Cadet, 1 damage to the Warden.
* 4 damage to the Cadet, 0 damage to the Warden.

The Cadet and the Warden deals their damage to your Seeker as normal.
Hope that casts some light.
:)

I don't have this card yet, but I've ordered it. It looks like an awesome card, though, and will surely make a good role as a small secret ace in my upcoming Soldier deck.

152878: Cenn's Tactician.author: KillerWhiskey
152878: Cenn's Tactician.text_parsed:
"When a creature blocks multiple creatures, which player determines the damage order? Does it work like banding, like blocking with multiple creatures, or something entirely different?"

You choose the order in which your creature is going to combat the opposing creatures - AFAIK there's no such thing as assigning the amount of damage it could deal.

For example, if you were to block a 2/2 and a 3/3 creature with a 4/4 creature of your own, you have a choice whether your creature is going to hit the 2/2 first, and send the rest of its damage to the 3/3 one, or hit the 3/3 first to forward the rest of its damage to the 2/2 creature. The point is that your creature first has to deal "lethal" damage (just enough damage for the opposing creature to be destroyed) for it to progress onto the next creature. This is very similar to the trample effect.

Keep in mind that, if your opponent plays, say, Giant Growth on the first creature in your "attack line", your creature will absolutely have to have enough power to kill the buffed creature before progressing onto the next one, even if the second creature in that attack line has low enough toughness for your creature to vanquish it. Also, if your creature has deathtouch, just one point of damage is enough to be considered "lethal".

As for this card - yeah it's badass. 5/5! Loyal Sentry would adore him.

152887: Spitebellows.author: Donovan_Fabian
152887: Spitebellows.text_parsed:
Where ancients tread + spite bellows = 11 damage whenever it enters and leaves play.

in response to cauldron of souls/cauldron haze, you can order the stack to make that work, it would enter play, sac., then return to play, and die immediately from having 0 toughness and leave again and do another 6. This of course, is if you don't have the mana to play it normally, since you could always leave it in play and give it persist when someone tries to kill it with a terminate. Keeping in mind its target creature only, and also keep in mind it is not a may ability, so if you have no other creature to target besides your own have to blast it.

To me the real value of this card is that even though it can be a creature, if I haven't drawn the 6 mana I need to play it that way, I can still evoke it for 3 and effectivley remove anything without shroud/indestructibility or higher than 6 toughness (which isn't very many creatures, besides walls and cards like sundering titan). In essence its almost exactly like a shriekmaw except it works when it leaves play instead of entering, and to this effect works differently with certain combos. The best thing about this card that really stands out is that it says when it "leaves play" not when it goes to graveyard, the ability works even if the creature is exiled or temporarily removed from play with spells like ghostway and otherworldly journey. You could play spitebellows, wait for an opponent to try to kill it or chump block it, then remove it with otherworldly journey, do 6 to a creature, and have it come back into play as an 8/3. Can also evoke infinite number of times with a paleoloth in play, since evoking it still plays the creature who is 6 power, allowing you to return a 5+ power creature from your graveyard. Pair that with a stuffy doll and six mana gives you 12 damage a turn to target opponent, though it would require a lot of set up to play stuffy doll, paleoloth, and a spite bellows together.
