Where ancients tread + spite bellows = 11 damage whenever it enters and leaves play.

in response to cauldron of souls/cauldron haze, you can order the stack to make that work, it would enter play, sac., then return to play, and die immediately from having 0 toughness and leave again and do another 6.  This of course, is if you don't have the mana to play it normally, since you could always leave it in play and give it persist when someone tries to kill it with a terminate.  Keeping in mind its target creature only, and also keep in mind it is not a may ability, so if you have no other creature to target besides your own have to blast it.

To me the real value of this card is that even though it can be a creature, if I haven't drawn the 6 mana I need to play it that way, I can still evoke it for 3 and effectivley remove anything without shroud/indestructibility or higher than 6 toughness (which isn't very many creatures, besides walls and cards like sundering titan).  In essence its almost exactly like a shriekmaw except it works when it leaves play instead of entering, and to this effect works differently with certain combos.  The best thing about this card that really stands out is that it says when it "leaves play" not when it goes to graveyard, the ability works even if the creature is exiled or temporarily removed from play with spells like ghostway and otherworldly journey.  You could play spitebellows, wait for an opponent to try to kill it or chump block it, then remove it with otherworldly journey, do 6 to a creature, and have it come back into play as an 8/3.  Can also evoke infinite number of times with a paleoloth in play, since evoking it still plays the creature who is 6 power, allowing you to return a 5+ power creature from your graveyard.  Pair that with a stuffy doll and six mana gives you 12 damage a turn to target opponent, though it would require a lot of set up to play stuffy doll, paleoloth, and a spite bellows together.

152893: Lightning Crafter.author: AssKickingBoots
152893: Lightning Crafter.text_parsed:
Combining this guy with Thornbite Staff is like gluing 3 Goblin Sharpshooters together, albeit at more mana cost overall (including equipping the staff, at least 10 cmc), and just as many cards to pull off (unless you champion a token). It's actually not as badass as you might think. I'd rather run Goblin Sharpshooter with a Basilisk Collar. Still, this a very effective card, especially in a deck that runs both it and Sharpshooter.

One intriguing thing someone mentioned is Championing Eternal Witness. Effectively, should your Lightning Crafter die, your Eternal Witness hits the battlefield and you can put him right back in your hand, then Champion the Witness again at your next main phase.

I do not think this guy is better than Royal Assassin in that RA can effectively shut down opponents' creatures entirely regardless of creature toughness, with a cheaper cmc, without having to Champion anything.

152904: Thornbite Staff.author: Mode
152904: Thornbite Staff.text_parsed:
Unfortunately this one is the worst one from the tribal equipment cycle, yet it can still find use.
It's a pity the activation cost wasn't reduced to , then it would be pretty crazy.

Well, but it still provides Goblin Sharpshooter's untap trigger.
So all we have to do is finding a Shaman creature that can shoot without using mana.
Lightning Crafter is the excellent choice for this. With him it's similar to having three Sharpshooters outside!
Like this your opponent will only have his fatties left, and given that you can afford other losses on your side you can even char these.

Valleymaker can do the same amount of damage as the Crafter, but costs two more and a mountain each time, so it's by far not that useful with this guy.

Vulshok Sorcerer and Vithian Stinger can also do this job.
Use Frostwielder if you don't want them to hit the graveyard.
This card can also help flipping Initate of Blood, which will also do a good job then since Goka the Unjust can give most creatures a Fatal Blow.

Spikeshot Goblin still needs mana, but can also work if you bring some buffs. Although you should rather look for synergy cards then, since a three card combo isn't worth trying in general.

Creatures with deathtouch will also do a great job with this card, although there aren't any Shaman deathtouchers available yet, except for Moonglove Changeling, as Ratinyourwallsvailable mentioned. to destroy the first creature each turn and for each further creature is also quite enjoyable.
Gorgon Flail could also find use given that you have a bunch of shooting Shamans in your deck anyways which can also make use of it.

You can also give this staff to Kiki-Jiki, Mirror Breaker for infinite creature sacrifice supply. By copying Orcish Bloodpainter or Tar Pitcher you could kill you opponent for example.

The equip cost is regrettably rediculously high, therefore i'd generally not use it with non-Shamans. Unless you really want to play it with Terminators like Avatar of Woe or Visara the Dreadful...

152904: Thornbite Staff.author: PineappleDisciple
152904: Thornbite Staff.text_parsed:
This card was practically MADE for Kiki-Jiki, Mirror Breaker. So many infinite combos.

Any creature that deals free damage (Mudbutton Torchrunner, Triskelion, etc.) and a sac outlet: infinite damage.
Any creature that gives at least two free mana (Palladium Myr, Workhorse) and a sac outlet: infinite mana.
A creature token generator (Myr Battlesphere, Siege-Gang Commander) and a sac outlet: infinite creatures.
Any free land-destruction creature (Goblin Settler, Avalanche Riders) and a sac outlet: destroy all your opponent's lands.
Ashnod's Altar/Phyrexian Altar and a creature: infinite mana.
Thermopod: infinite red mana.
Mogg Fanatic: infinite damage.
Goblin Bombardment and a creature: infinite damage.
Solemn Simulacrum and a sac outlet: infinite card draw/ land searching

Heck, it even attaches for free because Kiki-Jiki is a shaman! Just watch out: after a few EDH games, playing this card will make you a marked man.

152904: Thornbite Staff.author: Fanaticmogg
152904: Thornbite Staff.text_parsed:
Oh, you people with your quaint little "deathtouch + pinger" and "T: Destroy target creature" combos. You guys have no imagination.

Here's how you make a REAL Thornbite Staff combo:

Hell's Caretaker + Any creature with an ETB or LTB effect + Any other creature. I suggest Angel of Despair.

Creature that taps to create a token + a sac outlet. Good options include
Kazandu Tuskcaller (Shaman type!), Master of the Wild Hunt (same), Thraben Doomsayer (Mana-efficient!) Bloodline Keeper (Pretty damn good on its own), and Krenko, Mob Boss (Goblin tribal! Tons of options!).

Ghave, Guru of Spores + a creature with a tap ability. You can now pay 2 mana to untap that creature. I suggest Elvish Abberation, though the Archdruid and Bloom Tender can work too.

Kamahl, Fist of Krosa. Infinite Ice Storms.

I could go on, but I have a deck to build.

152934: Nevermaker.author: Oblivax
152934: Nevermaker.text_parsed: The first time i saw someone use a blink to get around the evoke sacrifice, I thought it seemed a little fishy, but i let it pass.  If you review the rules, specifically 702.72a, it's very clear that the sacrifice is PART of the casting cost, not a triggered effect.  Failure to sacrifice the creature makes the evoke fizzle and the creature goes to the graveyard.  It doesn't matter if the creature leaves the battlefield, it still must be sacrificed to fulfill the evoke cost. Any judge that misses this obviously hasn't read the rules closely enough.
152934: Nevermaker.text_posted: The first time i saw someone use a blink to get around the evoke sacrifice, I thought it seemed a little fishy, but i let it pass. 152934: Nevermaker.author: the_blind_pony
152934: Nevermaker.text_parsed:
Blink works here. "When" is a sure sign of a trigger.

Pay evoke cost. Creature etb's. Sacrifice trigger goes on the stack. Blink it. The creature is now a new item and the sacrifice trigger doesn't recognize it as the same creature.

152938: Idyllic Tutor.author: Gwafa_Hazid
152938: Idyllic Tutor.text_parsed: Really Mode? I thought there were a lot of great enchantments and enchantment-themed stuff comin outta that block. Enchanted Evening, the whole cycle of Demigod auras, two great creature control auras, Curse of Chains and Prison Term, Prismatic Omen, the greatest boon to WUBRG, the Reflection cycle, a bunch of enchants that used tribal types, even an enchant protection from Greater Auramancy. A lot of this was introduced flavorwise because the British Isles mythology was heavy on the glamour(i.e., Glamer Spinners, Glamerdye), which was a type of illusion cast over an individual to make them seem like something they weren't, or better than they were. Enchantments were far from being the Spotlight-Stealing Squad, but they were at least somewhat big in the block.
152938: Idyllic Tutor.text_posted: Really Mode? I thought there were a lot of great enchantments and enchantment-themed stuff comin outta that block. 152938: Idyllic Tutor.author: zk3
152938: Idyllic Tutor.text_parsed:
I think the reason fabricate is uncommon while this is a rare is because artifacts always had better search (Tinker being the most obvious example). However, enchantments had Sterling Grove or Enlightened Tutor at best, and a lot fewer tricks to get them into play.
However, I do think enchantments are mostly cheaper to cast than artifacts (due to them being colored) and have more powerful one-sided effects. Wizards is actively trying to make enchantments more relevant. Until then...

152977: Kinsbaile Borderguard.author: The_Murderauder
152977: Kinsbaile Borderguard.text_parsed:
@SoulShatterer: Actually, although that used to be the case, +1/+1 counters and -1/-1 counters now cancel eachother out, rather than modify p/t separately. So you can't have, say, five +1/+1 and three -1/-1 counters on the same creature; it would reduce down to two +1/+1 counters.

However, if this guy had no other counters on him, and was killed with a single -1/-1 counter, you would get one Kithkin token.

152980: Countryside Crusher.author: Mephastopheles
152980: Countryside Crusher.text_parsed:
How about this with Wheel of Sun and Moon and Selective Memory?

1. Play this giant
2. Cast Selective Memory, removing all of your nonlands
3. Cast Wheel of Sun & Moon
4. At the beginning of your upkeep, Countryside Crusher checks the top card of your lib, and tries to put it into the graveyard; the enchantment returns it to the bottom of your lib (I think), so you can cycle through your entire library of lands infinitely!

The only part I'm not sure about is whether the Wheel's ability triggers every time you put a land into the graveyard, or only at the end. It works pretty well either way.

As previously mentioned, in a low-curve aggro deck every land you draw after your first 3-4 is a bad draw, since you would much rather have a burn spell or a cheap creature. 152980: Countryside Crusher.author: Artscrafter
152980: Countryside Crusher.text_parsed:
@Mephastopheles: If I understand it correctly, you would not only not get any counters if you had Wheel of Sun and Moon out (as Musume said) but if you had used Selective Memory to ditch all your nonland cards you would end up in a forced infinite loop and draw the game.

If I'm reading the Crusher's effect correctly, all the repetitions are done as one action. However, the Wheel is a replacement effect, not a triggered ability. So you would reveal the top card, it's a land, and you put it on the bottom of your deck. Then you reveal the next top card, put it on the bottom of your deck, etc.

If I'm reading the Crusher's effect correctly, all the repetitions are done as one action. However, the Wheel is a replacement effect, not a triggered ability. So you would reveal the top card, it's a land, and  you put it on the bottom of your deck. Then you reveal the next top card, put it on the bottom of your deck, etc.

152980: Countryside Crusher.author: Salient
152980: Countryside Crusher.text_parsed:
"Countryside is on your side."

This guy's practically essential in burn decks, and not just because of his boost ability -- playing him ensures you'll never draw another land, which means you'll be drawing nothing but spells. It's perfect filtering for burn, which rarely runs anything with 4+ mana cost and therefore doesn't need any more land by the time it's topdecking. Crusher effectively turns your potential dead topdecks into +1/+1 counters.

Crusher also works well with the other burn staple creature, Grim Lavamancer, by ensuring you have a well-stocked graveyard to burn through.

152998: Ambassador Oak.author: Aaron_Forsythe
152998: Ambassador Oak.text_parsed:
Aarons Random Card Comment of the Day #11, 10/11/10

In a vacuum, I adore this card. I love creatures that make tokens, specifically as a subset of creatures that give you more than a cards worth of value. (Why should the máss removal and card drawing players be the only ones capable of generating such a resource advantage? Answer: They shouldnt.) On top of that, the card is about as simple and elegant as they come.

So simple and elegant, in fact, that Mark Rosewater claims to have submitted it as part of the design handoff for seven different sets, and it was removed all six times prior to Morningtide. Always codenamed Moose and Squirrela reference to an ancient cartoon called Rocky and Bullwinkle, for those of you not over 30it was initially designed for inclusion in Urzas Saga almost a decade before. It is ironic that the set it ultimately ended up being printed in not only didnt have squirrel tokens, but actually contained another green common creature that looked like a moose! (Game-Trail Changeling)

Why was it killed so many times before? Most often because a more on-theme card was deemed necessary for whatever set it was in. There is a lesson here about persistence, and a reminder that Magic design is rarely an exercise in instant gratification.

Ultimately, the fact that the card created creatures of two different types (Treefolk and Elf, both Warriors) are what made it fit well into Morningtide from designs perspective, but Im not sure how correct that philosophy was. The biggest flaw with Lorwyn and Morningtide, especially in limited, is that game states often degenerated into complex matrices of different races, clásses, changelings, and cards that could affect or target only some of what was in play. Figuring out what was going onand how to attack and blockwas more difficult in that block than any others in recent years, and I dont consider that a good thing. Im not saying that Ambássador Oak was part of the problem, but he certainly wasnt part of the solutionsuddenly your Treefolk deck had an Elf in play (or vice verse) and its a token, which is easy to lose track of. It is more irony, then, that the quality that allowed it to be printed is probably the reasonif there is onewhy it shouldnt have been. The card wasn't printed in a vacuum, but it might have been better if it had.

Perhaps he should have been called Irony-Root Treefolk.

152998: Ambassador Oak.author: Cheza
152998: Ambassador Oak.text_parsed:
@ Aaron:

Another post that uses a personal experience and overextend it until it sounds like anyone agrees. If you would have skipped creature types completely, there wouldn't have been a problem. If you would have used Fungus+Saproling, no problem either.

The stupid part about this block was that the switch from race to class was an overdose. The split into a 2x2 block didn't really help.

@ Token:
Come on. If you think that you can get lost with a single token including a relevant creature type, you would have never ever allowed artifacts that produce "token" copies of other artifacts/creatures. How stupid is this? Or what about Chronozoa? Tokens with counters?

In my opinion, R&D should reduce this token stupidness to the minimum. Searching for a copy or Looking at the top X cards and pick one card that fulfills a certain statement is much cooler and much more flavorful... and this would never ever produce problems about "keeping track".

153012: Veteran's Armaments.author: Mode
153012: Veteran's Armaments.text_parsed:
This card does a great job, tribal equipment rocks.
With Ballyrush Banneret or Daru Warchief this card can be played for or even no mana at all,
and you won't have to pay the equip cost most of the time.
Enlistment Officer will let you put this card into your hand.
The type itself synergizes with Auriok Steelshaper, Taj-Nar Swordsmith and Leonin Shikari,
the effect in a defensive way with Kjeldoran Royal Guard, Weathered Bodyguards, Ironfist Crusher, Palace Guard or Thoughtweft Trio.
And of course the effect is completely awesome on just any attacker, you get some sort of piledriver after all.

153012: Veteran's Armaments.author: __Silence__
153012: Veteran's Armaments.text_parsed: @TPmanW the effects don't last the whole time. In other words, once a creature is unequipped it no longer gets the bonus from that equipment. If you unequip it and put it onto one of the tokens the Hero will simply stay a 3/4 (unless you have OTHER enchants and equips STILL attached to it). Of course you also have to remember on a card that says when a creature ATTACKS or BLOCKS means that when the attackers/blockers are declared. The tokens won't trigger this event which would make it pointless to put the equip onto them anyway. If you are running a white deck and want something to run along side your combo a really really good option with this card is mistmeadow skulk. This means no large creatures that have a cc of 3 or more can block the mistmeadow and you can normally get a nice attack in. Hope this helps and see ya.

153012: Veteran's Armaments.author: TPmanW
153012: Veteran's Armaments.text_parsed: I've been experimenting with this and Hero of Bladehold. Put this on a creature the turn before you swing with the hero. When Hero of Bladehold makes it's token move the equipment over and both creatures get the bonus until end of turn. With the hero, it's tokens and the original creature swinging it's a guaranteed +4/+4 minimum bonus to two separate creatures.

153099: Oona's Blackguard.author: Chrisrawr
153099: Oona's Blackguard.text_parsed: There's really no debate about it. The text says that if a 1/1 comes into play, it gets 2 +1/+1 counters. this happens at the same time as the Blackguard's ability. That's why sigil captains are fun - they stack! Their ability doesn't care about the power/toughness after the creature has entered the battlefield, only as it does.
153099: Oona's Blackguard.text_posted: There's really no debate about it. Their ability doesn't care about the power/toughness after the creature has entered the battlefield, only as it does.

153099: Oona's Blackguard.author: WhiteWizard42
153099: Oona's Blackguard.text_parsed:
Chrisrawr, you're wrong, it doesn't work like that. The blackguard gives the tokens a counter as they come into play (it has a static ability that affects coming into play), then when the sigil captain checks the tokens' P/T it's a 2/2 and so the captain's ability doesn't trigger (because it has a triggered ability that doesn't activate until something is already in play.

Two sigil captains don't even stack, because they have a conditional IF clause that is rechecked on ability resolution. the first would make it a 3/3 and the other fizzles.
153099: Oona's Blackguard.text_posted:
Chrisrawr, you're wrong, it doesn't work like that.  The blackguard gives the tokens a counter as they come into play (it has a static ability that affects coming into play), then when the sigil captain checks the tokens' P/T it's a 2/2 and so the captain's ability doesn't trigger (because it has a triggered ability that doesn't activate until something is already in play.

Two sigil captains don't even stack, because they have a conditional IF clause that is rechecked on ability resolution.  the first would make it a 3/3 and the other fizzles.

153099: Oona's Blackguard.author: theelk801
153099: Oona's Blackguard.text_parsed: Come on people, @WhiteWizard42 is correct. Oona's Blackguard sets up a replacement effect that gives the creature a +1/+! counter as it enters the battlefield. Therefore, if it's a 1/1, it enters as a 2/2 due to the counters. Sigil Captain's ability doesn't trigger either, as it has an intervening if clause and checks upon triggering and upon resolution. So when a Rogue enters the battlefield, Sigil Captain doesn't trigger, and even if it didn't get the counter (if there's no Blackguard), then only one Sigil Captain's ability would resolve anyway.
153099: Oona's Blackguard.text_posted: Come on people, @WhiteWizard42 is correct. [autocard]Oona's Blackguard[/autocard] sets up a replacement effect that gives the creature a +1/+! counter as it enters the battlefield. Therefore, if it's a 1/1, it enters as a 2/2 due to the counters. [autocard]Sigil Captain[/autocard]'s ability doesn't trigger either, as it has an intervening if clause and checks upon triggering and upon resolution. So when a Rogue enters the battlefield, Sigil Captain doesn't trigger, and even if it didn't get the counter (if there's no Blackguard), then only one Sigil Captain's ability would resolve anyway.

153101: Seething Pathblazer.author: tcollins
153101: Seething Pathblazer.text_parsed:
@Tigt: No, I don't think this works, since the evoke ability states the creature is sacrificed as it enters the battlefield, and you cannot sacrifice a single permenant to gain two different effects. An example is:

I have a Ravenous Baloth and Culling Dais in play, you target my Ravenous Baloth with Doom Blade in response I could sacrifice it using Ravenous Baloth's own ability and gain 4 life or i can sacrifice it to Culling Dais and put a charge counter on Culling Dais. However i cannot sacrifice it for 4 life and put a charge counter on Culling Dais, since you can only gain one effect from sacrificing a permanent.

In the case of casting a creature for it's evoke cost, you're already sacrificing it (as part of the evoke mechanic) so you can't sacrifice it as it comes into play. However most of the evoke cards still have synergy with this card, since they often have abilities that result from them leaving play as well, such as Offalsnout.

153101: Seething Pathblazer.author: Tigt
153101: Seething Pathblazer.text_parsed:
Apparently this is used to sacrifice elementals that got evoked before they evaporate, or at least, that's how I heard it. Does that work?

EDIT @tcollins: Before I put a bombo in my deck, I tried looking it up on cranial insertion. It appears it does work:

Q: Can I make a Burnt Offering out of an evoked Ingot Chewer? I've always heard you can't sacrifice something to two different effects.

A: You've heard right, but that won't stop you here! When you cast Chewie for his evoke cost, the sacrifice is part of a triggered ability that pops up when he enters the battlefield. You can respond with your Offering, and pay the cost of the offering by sacrificing him. You wouldn't be able to sacrifice him for any other costs, but the evoke sacrifice isn't a cost; it's an effect.

Source: http://www.cranialinsertion.com/article/239
153101: Seething Pathblazer.text_posted:
Apparently this is used to sacrifice elementals that got evoked before they evaporate, or at least, that's how I heard it. Does that work?

153102: Borderland Behemoth.author: Japicx
153102: Borderland Behemoth.text_parsed:
One of the obscure advantages of this card (and of tribal cards in general) is that they are fiercely resistant to creature-control builds.
I once played against such a build; it was a blue Counterbalance-Sensei's Divining Top deck of the kind that's supposed to frustrate Giant players and make them feel mentally inferior, but Giants ended up on top. First, I cleared the board of his potentially supremely annoying Serendib Sorcerer with my Thundercloud Shaman. Then he played Keiga, the Tidestar. I attacked with both of my 12/12 Behemoths, Keiga died, he took control of one, it shrunk to a measly 4/4, and that was the game.

Giants are also great against Counterbalance because their CMCs begin at 4, and the most important ones have costs of 6 or 7. All I'm saying is sometimes you just can't outsmart raw power.

153104: Rage Forger.author: Fabercastel
153104: Rage Forger.text_parsed:
Hidden gem that's a lot more powerful than it looks.

I run it in an elementals deck with Flamekin Harbinger, Smokebraider, and Incandescent Soulstoke - all of which are shamans. And, of course, it's got mulldrifters, reveillarks, and shriekmaws like any elemental deck should.

Turn 1: Harbinger
Turn 2: Smokebraider, Swing for 1.
Turn 3: Soulstoke, Swing for 4.
Turn 4: Rageforger, Swing for 9, 3 more to the face.

Not only do additional Rageforgers bring more +1/+1 counters to the table, but they will both trigger, dealing 2 damage for each creature that has a +1/+1 counter on it - they don't even need to be shamans. An additional Rageforger on the 5th turn means you're attacking with 4 4/4's, each dealing 2 more to the opponment whether or not they're blocked.

The deck doesn't even need to play out like this - you can evoke mulldrifters early on, chump block with the harbinger, and then bring them both back via soulstoked reveillark (5/4 haste). Stack the triggered cop abilities so that you search your library for an elemental before you draw the 2 cards, and you can find solutions like wispmares, shreikmaws, ingot chewers, or even horde of notions at a whim.

Not the most powerful deck in the world, but it's an inexpensive beatdown deck that's fun and versatile. Able to recover from board sweeps, doesn't run out of gas after taking a person down in multiplayer, and has a lot of answers.

153135: Earwig Squad.author: PolskiSuzeren
153135: Earwig Squad.text_parsed:
@Need:

He didn't say that goblins usually win BEFORE you can play this. He said that the game is just about over by the time you could use it, meaning that the game is already heavily in your favor. Here's a little overkill:

T1 goblin lackey. T2 swing (19) drop in siege-gang commander, play goblin piledriver. T3 play goblin chieftain, swing with three 3/3 tokens, a 2/2 lackey, a 3/3 siege-gang, a 2/2 chieftain, and a whopping 14/3 piledriver. That's 30 damage on that turn, 31 damage dealt in total, and it makes the earwig squad look like a waste of precious mana.

Too much? Ok, how's this: T1 lackey. T2 swing (19) drop in piledriver, play second piledriver.) T3 chieftain, swing with a 2/2 lackey, a 2/2 chieftain, and two 8/3 piledrivers, coming to a total of 20 damage on that turn.

Ok, ok. ONE last example, if you still think that's too much.

T1 lackey, T2 swing and drop in goblin warchief, then play goblin matron, fetching a piledriver. T3 play piledriver and, hell, we'll go with cycling a gempalm incinerator to wipe out a blocker. Why not?

That swings for 11 on T3, 12 damage in total.

Tell me, in any of these scenarios, where would it have been better to play the earwig?

In summation: Earwig squad may have been ok in lorwyn standard at the time, but on the whole, it's nothing but a lower class wannabe goblin when compared to all the others that see play.

153137: Boldwyr Heavyweights.author: Japicx
153137: Boldwyr Heavyweights.text_parsed:
I think that it's worth pointing out the control potential of a card like this. Your opponent gets the chance to put his best creature on the battlefield for free, and if you're smart, you'll have a way to deal with it.

True, you could destroy it with t Breaking Point as suggested, but that requires your opponent to already be in such a tight spot that killing every creature is preferable to taking six damage. Leave some mana open for a Traitorous Instinct, Act of Treason or other such red one-turn control card (or a blue one, maybe, but Giants and blue seem to be at odds with each other), grab your opponent's Kozilek, Butcher of Truth or Ulamog, the Infinite Gyre and laugh at his shocked expression. Of course, there's a long list of ways this could go wrong (the list being comprised of every significant creature with protection from red, shroud, or a notable come-into-play ability), but in that case, Obsidian Battle-Axe makes a great back-up plan. Use the Axe regardless.

The mana requirements for this shouldn't be too steep, since as a good Giant player you naturally run four Stinkdrinker Daredevils. This play is strictly casual for sure, but I doubt that anyone will expect a control play centered on a Giant.

153137: Boldwyr Heavyweights.text_parsed:
MarlinFlake
"Emrakul can't be targeted by colored spells"
1) A spell is any card that is on the stack
2) Colored abilities like those of fatestitcher, Cunning Sparkmage and Gilded Drake are not cards and therefore not spells, however if those cards were on the stack and used those abilities on the stack then they can not target Emrakul because there sources are from colored spells
3) "When 'Name' enters the battlefield" is a triggered ability from something on the battlefield and not the stack
4) I can read just fine and eak1801 I'm taking your combo :D

153137: Boldwyr Heavyweights.author: scumbling1
153137: Boldwyr Heavyweights.text_parsed:
The problem comes when they get a creature so big that red can't effectively burn it. Red really struggles with killing larger creatures, and the Heavyweights can land you into trouble in this area. Also, this notion of 'I'll just lure out your creature and kill it' goes two ways: what if the opponent takes the opportunity to grab their Shriekmaw -- or worse -- Angel of Despair? You're then behind in tempo and card advantage.

Sure, this card is probably best used as a gimmicky / fun card to be comboed with Shadow of Doubt / Leonin Arbiter / Stifle, or to maybe to be used with Repercussion, or perhaps even to be played in a "Group Hug" multiplayer setting. I still would have liked it to have had haste added on there. That way, it would serve well as a sort of high-risk high-reward Ball Lightning.

153138: Graceful Reprieve.author: jonrds
153138: Graceful Reprieve.text_parsed:
This card is actually fairly underpowered compared to the other options out there (most notably Undying Evil and Cauldron Haze). It is also available in "seal" form with Angelic Renewal and (repeatable) aura form with Gift of Immortality. The main advantage this has over all the other revives is that it is the only repeatable one (no counter interactions) that fits on a stick (unlike the more powerful effects, like Second Sunrise and Faith's Reward).

@RiftenBlack
You missed that this specifies "owner's control". Grim Return can be used to steal an enemy creature after killing it with something like Doom Blade, which makes it almost a black False Demise.
@Adunar
This triggers on death and puts it under its owners control. The Treacherous Pit-Dweller triggers on entering the battlefield, and switches control (so it will go to an opponent of the owner, no matter who cast this). So you can potentially get 3 uses out of your opponent's dweller with this, (1 from undying, 1 from this, and 1 from the next round of undying).
If you cast this during your opponents first use of Dweller, it gets more complicated. If it is your turn, undying will trigger second, resolve first, and give you the Dweller with the counter. If it is your opponents turn, this will trigger second, resolve first, and give you the Dweller without the counter. But both those situations are pretty dumb, since you would be getting the Dweller anyway.
TL;DR: Don't run this and Dweller in the same deck. But feel free to use this to screw over someone else who uses Dweller.

153139: Bramblewood Paragon.author: Donovan_Fabian
153139: Bramblewood Paragon.text_parsed:
The thing I like best about this card is it's not reduced to only dealing with elves, it will work on any warrior, including giants and other large type creatures who you always wished had trample while simultaneously making them bigger. Also, combos very nicely with ajani goldmane, giving all creatures +1/1 counters, vigilance, and trample. Juniper order ranger doesn't hurt either. Can pair with graft decks, to activate graft abilities without actually moving counters around, because creatures come into play with a +1/1 counter.

Hook her up with tanglesap and your creatures can do damage during an attack phase without your opponent doing any. Pair with echoing courage for some fun overrun type advantage, or primal bellow.

153158: Roar of the Crowd.author: themicronaut
153158: Roar of the Crowd.text_parsed:
I would like to jump into the this vs. Mob Justice debate.

First, they have slight but important differences to each other, and I can see situations where they would both be useful. That being said Mob Justice is the better card.

Sure, this targets creatures and players, but you have to choose a creature type and it costs 4 mana. For 4 mana in red you can do much better than this. Mob Justice costs half and doesn't care about the creature type. In practice MJ can do a fair amount of justice, especially if you imprint it on an Isochron Scepter and throw some token generators out there.

153163: Greatbow Doyen.author: GrimjawxRULES
153163: Greatbow Doyen.text_parsed:
@Lord_Andrak: I think you read the card wrong - Greatbow Doyen only causes creatures to deal damage to players.
If one of your Archers deals damage to a creature, then Greatbow Doyen causes your Archer to deal that much damage to the creature's controller. If multiple Archers deal damage to a a creature (say you blocked a Serra Angel with two Ezuri's Archers), Greatbow Doyen triggers once for each time your Archers deal damage, resulting in 8 damage damage being dealt to your opponent.

Some rules clarification (in case it ever becomes necessary):
Trample:
If you somehow give a large Archer trample and attack with it... let's say you've got an 8/8 Archer with trample, and it's blocked by a 4/4 creature. You assign 8 damage to the blocker (resulting in the blocker taking 4 damage and the last 4 being dealt to your opponent), and Greatbow Doyen causes your 8/8 Archer to deal 4 damage to your opponent. In other words, Greatbow Doyen doesn't count the damage assigned to creatures, but rather, it counts the damage being dealt.

Deathtouch:
Creatures with deathtouch can still deal more than 1 damage to other creatures even though 1 deathtouch damage is considered lethal. As such, you can have Thornweald Archer assign 2 points of damage to a single creature, and Greatbow Doyen will then cause Thornweald Archer to deal 2 damage to that creature's controller.

Stacking:
Yes, Greatbow Doyen does stack. If you've got 2 copies of Greatbow Doyen on the battlefield and your Thornweald Archer deals 2 damage to a creature, both copies of Greatbow Doyen will trigger, causing your Thornweald Archer to deal 2 x 2 damage to your opponent (for a total of 4).

Damage-triggered abilities:
Abilities that trigger when a creature deals damage also triggers when Greatbow Doyen causes an Archer to deal damage to a player. This means that Umezawa's Jitte equipped to an Archer you control gains 4 counters when that Archer deals damage to a creature.
Likewise, if your somehow manage to make Stigma Lasher become an Archer (through for example Runed Stalactite) and it deals damage to a creature, then that creature's controller will recieve damage from Stigma Lasher and will be unable to gain life the rest of the game.

153163: Greatbow Doyen.author: OmegaSerris
153163: Greatbow Doyen.text_parsed:
If they really wanted to make a great archer lord, they should have dropped the "lord" effect (+1/+1) and just given them vigilance. Extra power on a creature that needs to tap doesn't help much except in blocking situations. Usually power boost are to promote aggressive actions while his second ability wants you to keep your archers untapped to 'ping'. As is, you have to make a choice to take advantage of the boost and swing, or use his ability and ping for (usually) less damage but possibly a creature kill.

Don't get me wrong, I like him. He isn't a bad card, but this is just what I think. Something else funny, he is an archer without a ping ability himself.

If they really wanted to make a great archer lord, they should have dropped the "lord" effect (+1/+1) and just given them vigilance. Extra power on a creature that needs to tap doesn't help much except in blocking situations. Usually power boost are to promote aggressive actions while his second ability wants you to keep your archers untapped to 'ping'. As is, you have to make a choice to take advantage of the boost and swing, or use his ability and ping for (usually) less damage but possibly a creature kill.

Don't get me wrong, I like him. He isn't a bad card, but this is just what I think. Something else funny, he is an archer without a ping ability himself.

153163: Greatbow Doyen.author: scubbo
153163: Greatbow Doyen.text_parsed:
@GrimjawxRULES - this is utter nitpicking, so please forgive me, but what you wrote isn't *quite* accurate:

> You assign 8 damage to the blocker (resulting in the blocker taking 4 damage and the last 4 being dealt to your opponent)

Trample doesn't *automatically* mean that any "leftover" damage is assigned to the defending player. Rather, it offers you the opportunity to do so, once all blocking creatures have been assigned lethal damage. Assigning 8 damage to the blocker would result in 8 damage to the blocker - assigning 4 damage to the blocker, and 4 damage to the opponent, would have the result you described.

This would actually come into play if you had two Greatbow Doyens out. In this case, you'd actually *want* to have your 8/8 assign 8 damage to the blocker (rather than 4 to the blocker and 4 trample damage), because then the full 8 damage would be "doubled" by the Doyens, rather than just 4.

Still. Amazing mechanics, amazing flavor, amazing card.

I'm not sure why this card's rating is so low. Definite solid card, with lots of potential. Easily 4/5 in the right deck.

153280: Auntie's Snitch.author: MisterAction
153280: Auntie's Snitch.text_parsed:
Hm. I'm not sure how I feel about this edition of the Nether Shadow pedigree. He looks like he should be wonderful, but I haven't enjoyed him as much as I'd hoped. He'd be overpowered if he could block, but as it stands he's completely invalidated if the opponent controls a single creature with first strike or toughness of 4. And if he gets killed by combat damage he won't be in the graveyard in time for his recursion to trigger.

I may just be spoiled by Gravecrawler. Comes out sooner, can be brought back more cheaply, with less fuss and more than once per turn, and with tribal support he can easily be a 5/4, have deathrouch, or be sac fodder to a Fleshbag Marauder or Grimgrin. Maybe goblins can use this guy better than rogues, but goblins are a very powerful archetype so I assume they have better choices.

Ah well. Still better than Akuta, Born of Ash.

153450: Chameleon Colossus.author: ChaoticNature
153450: Chameleon Colossus.text_parsed:
This is the best green creature in all of Magic. For the purpose it serves of course - that being to beat your opponent over the head. So excluding Birds of Paradise and other green creatures not meant for attacking. I even think this is slightly better than Tarmogoyf. An 8/8 for 4 WITH pro black? And no drawback at all? Yeah. Chameleon Colossus makes Erhnam Djinn look like utter garbage, and that was the best green creature for 4 way back when.

I love the art too. Dude has another dude for a foot, and one dude appears to be sliding down his leg! The card is epic win. I just ordered 3 foils of this guy for $33, and can't wait til they get here.

Also, why are some of you so concerned with slapping Rancor or some kind of equipment on him? Here's a pro tip: HE DOESN'T FREAKING NEED IT. It's not worth the investment when he is already that good all by himself. It's just irrelevant, why would you go out of your way to do something like that.

153450: Chameleon Colossus.author: Tyrus77
153450: Chameleon Colossus.text_parsed:
The awesomeness of this card just increased. Today my good buddy had him, an Elvish Archdruid, a Perfect, and Onmath (his EDH general).

In our 4 way 1v1v1v1 EDH game another friend forced him to sac 2 attacking creatures with odds, with 255 mana in his pool he decided to dump his mana pool into Chameleon Colossus. 255/4 (the 2GG) is about 63, and Chameleon colossus at a 6/6 already became a massive 5.53e19/5.53e19 beast hitting with no blockers.

It was truly an epic finish to a well fought EDH round. that 5.53e19 is 55 Quintillon, 3000 Quadrillion for those that don't know the numbers.

153453: Gilt-Leaf Archdruid.author: Donovan_Fabian
153453: Gilt-Leaf Archdruid.text_parsed: frankly, not all that impressed.. 3/3 for a 5 mana cost, and if your opponent sees you putting something like this on the field they aren't going to hesitate to destroy it/cancel it.  Even if you got it on the field when has their ever been a game where you typically get 7+ creatures on the field at the same time without them getting destroyed?   It would be much easier if it were elves and not druids as well, there are lots of ways of getting elves or elf tokens out there. 153453: Gilt-Leaf Archdruid.author: Morgrath
153453: Gilt-Leaf Archdruid.text_parsed: Donovan, it's the fact that it requires so much to set up that draws people to this card. Druids, like the other less popular tribes of Lorwyn (Archers for example), are there to be played by Johnnys. I personally love druids, and with the amount of mana ramp a mono green deck can get going, you be dropping four or five little druids a turn, keeping your hand topped up and creating great board presence. As has been said, you can 'force-tap' your druids for the steal effect, so summoning sickness isn't an issue - the archdruid plus the four or five creatures you just summoned, plus whatever you had out previously, and you've got yourself a huge amount of mana to drop into finishers; my personal favourites being Howl of the Night Pack or Jolrael, Empress of Beasts.

153453: Gilt-Leaf Archdruid.author: Gwafa_Hazid
153453: Gilt-Leaf Archdruid.text_parsed: Very nice, use with early-game mana accelerator-druids, like Heritage Druid, Devoted Druid, and Llanowar Elves for best results. Tap em for mana, then tap em to take lands. Use some basics, Terramorphic Expanse, and Kodama's Reach to thin your deck out beautifully, allowing you to get trumps/druids every turn, and play them w/ this guy on the field, and top your hand off again to get more druids and more fodder for your Heritage Druid, so's you can play them druids you're drawing. Include some Elvish Archdruids to pump your weenie druids for some cursory defenses, then maim face with Howl of the Night Pack, Jolrael, Empress of Beasts, or, my personal favorite, Overrun with masses of elves.

153453: Gilt-Leaf Archdruid.author: OmegaSerris
153453: Gilt-Leaf Archdruid.text_parsed:
No, he doesn't trigger himself. Abilities (unless otherwise stated) are only active when the permanent is on the field. That's why you can Counterspell (by targeting) a creature with Shroud on the stack. Until it is a creature (not a creature spell), Shroud isn't active.

There are exceptions. Like Cycling, which is only active while it is a 'card' in your hand.

153453: Gilt-Leaf Archdruid.author: Stinga
153453: Gilt-Leaf Archdruid.text_parsed:
For anyone having the same worries as Skew remember that this guy's ability is instant. That means you can drop him and leave your armies of druids on the field, untapped and ready to go. If your enemy swings, then block appropriately and save yourself. Next turn you should be able to replace whatever druids died with your lands and "force tap" them, especially with Mr Archdruid's cantrip ability. If they try something funny just steal all their land in response. Sure, you may lose your Archdruid to a bolt but once you have all their lands they are hardly a threat. And if they don't try anything on their turn? Just take it all at their end step.

@Rykon8472 I feel a sudden need to hit report abuse. ;)

154160: Deglamer.author: boneclub
154160: Deglamer.text_parsed: This is seeing GP play people! In extended, it's a great meta-call. Wurmcoil Engine (AKA "Best Titan In Extended") is very awkward to use a Naturalize on, but kicking it back into the deck is great! Also, drawing a Bitterblossom late-game in the aggro matchup (As most green-based decks are) is very suckish. Prismatic Omen also gets shut down. Sure, they can Wargate it back into play, but that could have happened with any other copy in there deck, plus this shuts down Sun Titan recursion.

154163: Diviner's Wand.author: BastianQoU
154163: Diviner's Wand.text_parsed:
@ICEFANG:
This card can not give you infinite mana. But by playing this when you have inf mana, you can draw out your library, play your cards, yada yada. It lets any color draw cards by being able to use any color mana for its costs.

There's quite a few ways to get infinite mana. The most recent combo is 2 Myr Galvanizers and a Palladium Myr. With those three and Diviner's Wand, you can draw as many cards as you want.

As far as the card goes, it would be beautiful in a deck sporting wizards (duh) and the previously mentioned Training Grounds. Even without those boosts, this is a nice equipment. is a little costly for +1/+1 and flying on your own turns, but being able to repeatedly draw in any color at instant speed with the addition of colorless firebreathing makes the cost fair.

154164: Obsidian Battle-Axe.author: scumbling1
154164: Obsidian Battle-Axe.text_parsed: I like this card for casual games. Haste is great, and the bonus to size is respectable. Perhaps what I like most about it is the warriors that it interacts with themselves; Keldon Marauders get a lot better with the Axe out, as does Goblin Gavaleer. You can get an Unsummon and an attack out of Stingscourger, even if you don't want to pay the Echo cost; it's a similar situation with Mogg War Marshal. Reassembling Skeleton gets a lot of opportunities to wield the Axe for free, and even if the Haste doesn't matter to it, at least the pump makes the utility creature somewhat imposing.

154164: Obsidian Battle-Axe.author: Elegy
154164: Obsidian Battle-Axe.text_parsed:
Obviously best in a warrior deck. I use this in Tolsimir Wolfblood EDH. The deck doesn't have a ton of synergy, but having this out really helps.
If you want haste, you can just use Lightning Greaves, but this clearly has a different angle to it.
For example, Brighthearth Banneret makes this cost less. Champion it with Unstoppable Ash, because you can.
Other than that, there are better equipment, if you aren't doing warriors. Sword of Vengeance comes to mind.

154164: Obsidian Battle-Axe.author: Equinox523
154164: Obsidian Battle-Axe.text_parsed:
This reminds me a bit of Ronin Warclub for warriors. This can be quite devastating with proper support - Wrecking Ogre would swing for 10, and Nova Chaser for 12.

Other fun stuff:

- Run with Jor Kadeen, the Prevailer, Bleak Coven Vampires or Ezuri's Brigade, even helping to activate their Metalcraft abilities.

- The extra 1 toughness allows Hunted Troll to bust through his faery pursuers and survive without regenerating, even if your opponent blocks with them all at once.

- Viashino Sandstalker.

154164: Obsidian Battle-Axe.author: Lash_of_Dragonbreath
154164: Obsidian Battle-Axe.text_parsed:
I would run this over Lightning Greaves in EDH if my general was a warrior. Shroud is a little overrated anyway in a format where, if they don't kill your creature in response to equipping Greaves, it's going to eat a board wipe soon anyway.
Specially... Brion Stoutarm? It buffs him to 6 power, which is even more relevant with lifelink. Then you can put the auto-equip to good use with other Giants, swinging and then flinging them with Brion.

157428: Slithermuse.author: Oblivax
157428: Slithermuse.text_parsed: The first time i saw someone use a blink to get around the evoke sacrifice, I thought it seemed a little fishy, but i let it pass.  If you review the rules, specifically 702.72a, it's very clear that the sacrifice is PART of the casting cost, not a triggered effect.  Failure to sacrifice the creature makes the evoke fizzle and the creature goes to the graveyard.  It doesn't matter if the creature leaves the battlefield, it still must be sacrificed to fulfill the evoke cost. Any judge that misses this obviously hasn't read the rules closely enough.
157428: Slithermuse.text_posted: The first time i saw someone use a blink to get around the evoke sacrifice, I thought it seemed a little fishy, but i let it pass. 157428: Slithermuse.author: blurrymadness
157428: Slithermuse.text_parsed:
Consider Turn to Mist and Ghostly Flicker

Works really well in a deck focused on bouncing. If you bounce lands then you're going to really stall them and they'll have tons more cards than you. If you instead bounce tons of creatures and things they'll still have more cards by a good margin. This guy allows you two options; start moving in for the kill (or block) and net you card advantage a little later, or (potentially) draw you a bunch of cards now so you can finish the game.


@Oblivax
I assume you derived your name from "Oblivious", which you clearly are. Even the rulings *right on the card* tell you it's a triggered effect. To quote:

"4/1/2008 Whether evoke's sacrifice ability triggers when the creature enters the battlefield depends on whether the spell's controller chose to pay the evoke cost, not whether he or she actually paid it (if it was reduced or otherwise altered by another ability, for example)."

Anything that triggers not only uses the stack, but can be responded to. That ruling is from over 5 years ago; so I know you didn't just miss it because it came later, you missed it out of willful ignorance.

157432: Meadowboon.author: Oblivax
157432: Meadowboon.text_parsed: The first time i saw someone use a blink to get around the evoke sacrifice, I thought it seemed a little fishy, but i let it pass.  If you review the rules, specifically 702.72a, it's very clear that the sacrifice is PART of the casting cost, not a triggered effect.  Failure to sacrifice the creature makes the evoke fizzle and the creature goes to the graveyard.  It doesn't matter if the creature leaves the battlefield, it still must be sacrificed to fulfill the evoke cost. Any judge that misses this obviously hasn't read the rules closely enough.
